title: What is your biggest achievement in life? - Quora

response.answer_text: Being a good wife and a good mother. Those are the highest achievements I have and hope to continue. I have been told by numerous individuals including my husband that I am a good wife and a good mother. I send my daughter to the best private school possible and I would love to send my stepchildren there but that is not up to me it is up to my husband’s ex-wife and she does not agree. I spend time with my child every day and we are extremely open. I have taught her from age 6 that if she makes a mistake and she comes to me first she will not get in trouble the first time. If it happens again, and she tells me first, she will be in less trouble. She is extremely comfortable talking with me about her body changes as well as boys. She is only 11 but I hope this will continue throughout her life. She has openly said that she likes to talk to me about these things because she knows I will not talk to anyone else and she cannot count on the children at her school to keep the secrets. As far as being a wife, I am constantly asking my husband what I can do to improve. I make sure to satisfy every need he has. There is nothing too small that he could request for me to do. He provides for our family the most. He is a wonderful man so I strive to be a wonderful wife. We have great communication and I choose not to be a nagging wife and I don’t constantly bring up the past. If I ask him to do something and he doesn’t I do not get angry. Marriage isn’t about who goes to the grocery store. We fight rarely and when we do we are able to fix it within a matter of minutes because we stop what we are doing and communicate. I refuse to be a wife that nags or complains when he is not abusive or a liar. I encourage all who are married to ask their partners what they could do to improve their marriage. You’d be surprised on the answers and how simple it could be.

Erik was born gorgeous. At sixteen, Erik had long blonde hair, a smile that could melt the coldest of hearts and a body the Gods were jealous of. Erik represents perfection in my eyes.  My brother Erik and I were raised by a single mom, our Mom. My Mom has four sisters and countless female cousins. That gave Erik and I a very deep appreciation for the challenges all single parents face. Erik is my only sibling and younger brother by two years and nine months. At forty years old the small age gap no longer matters. At eleven years old it made all the difference in the world.  Born into dysfunction and raised by a parent who struggled with addiction, we found ourselves exposed to adult problems, often. Mom's boyfriends were what we swore we'd never become. The first time we fought back, Erik was nine. Garrett took a shot at Mom in our kitchen. I was next on the hit list and fell easily. Before he could raise his hand the third time, Erik charged from the back door straight towards him. My kid brother lifted a six foot man, that I thought was going to kill me, up into the air and launched him through two pantry doors. That would be a turning point in the lives of two brothers. One by one, in short order, we would take Mom's boyfriends out and keep her single for years. If my instigation and manipulation wasn't enough to chase them away, Erik used brute force. We were a formidable team. Our blood ties and history made our relationship strong, unbreakable. Throughout our teens and twenties we did everything together. Every job we worked was together. We lived together and dated sisters together. We thought our way through troubles and when that didn't work, well, brute force did.  Yes, Erik is a holding a monkey!  Erik was and is the man I most admire. He is part of me and we are part of each other. We started shooting dope together somewhere in our twenties. Two or three years ago, we were both trying to kick. I invited him over to my apartment one afternoon to plan a birthday party for our Mom. We talked, had a nice dinner and just caught up. Trying to kick dope and kicking dope are different. Trying means we were still shooting, but knew it wouldn't last forever. We cop'd a few bags and made arrangements for him to stay the night. We each shot a bag and I watched as the life drained from his face. His bright beautiful smile slowly fell as he slumped forward. I knew what was happening. At that point I had plenty of experience with death. I didn't panic in the sense that I was frozen, but I was certainly scared. I checked for a pulse that I knew wasn't going to be there. I called 911 immediately and began CPR. It was almost ten minutes until rescue personal would arrive. When I was relieved by med-techs, I broke down in tears. Erik was taken to Pottstown Memorial Hospital and I was right there with him. After about six hours, Erik came to. He knew he had overdosed in my apartment. Erik never shot up again. I was and am so proud of him. The police interviewed him while he was in the hospital and told him what had happened, that I had saved his life. Last year I quit shooting dope and we finally talked about what happened that night. I told him that saving his life was the best thing I ever did. He slowly cracked that beautiful smile, the one he has me to thank for, and said, “I kicked Garrett’s ass when he tried to kill you, guess we’re finally even.” I couldn't believe it! My little brother still putting my ass in check. Leon

Getting past the awkward hump that came after going 100% all in on my dreams. For three months, I was in a seriously unenjoyable funk. I had quit my job, sold all of my stuff and was backpacking the world. Yet I wasn’t happy. I was drowning in self doubt and overcome by feelings of failure, disappointment and confusion. For ninety days, I could not figure myself out. Because I had traveled to ten countries, met new people from all over the world and experienced an entirely new lifestyle-I was no longer the person I was when I first embarked on this journey. I wasn’t the me that I knew. I had outgrown her. I also wasn’t the person that I thought I would be. I wasn't a notable online writer, I wasn’t making money and I wasn’t happy. Feeling lost in your own skin is an interesting feeling. It’s like being in your home but none of your stuff is there. You realize that it’s just walls and windows, wood and shingles. The foundation is there, but everything inside is gone. There’s no where to sit. No telephone to call anybody. It feels extremely lonely. I sat in this empty home, within myself, for three months. It took ninety whole day for me to realize that was happening was exactly what I had been wishing for. My life was changing. Everything had been taken out of my home because it no longer belonged there. My life had upgraded and I didn’t need to bring all of the old furniture with me. The walls were bare so that I would be able to hang anything new that I wanted. The rooms were empty so that I could hand pick what my new sofa was going to look like. The emptiness was an opportunity. Change was going to refill my “home” with new treasures. I was growing up and transitioning into a new phase of my life where I was going to need new skills, personality traits and perspectives to succeed. I went from feeling incredibly lost and quite sad to liberated and passionate. I was reawakened to the opportunity that is life. My greatest achievement has been to open my eyes to the beauty of change. I’m now being incredibly specific as to what I’ll allow into my new home. That awkward hump, while feeling like some of the worst months of my life, was one of the best predicaments that could have happened to me. It reminded me why everybody doesn’t end up going for their dreams, because it’s mentally exhausting. It showed me that I was strong enough to attain the lifestyle of my dreams, because each tough situation is an epiphany waiting to be discovered. I am grateful for the awkward hump and those painful few months. I am ready for the incredible opportunities that will come from pushing past tough times and continuing to go all in on my goals. The day I had this epiphany.  Eva Gutierrez on Instagram

Growing up, I've always dreamed about walking with both my feet on the ground. Normally. I was born too early, by 7 months. I have autism and cerebral palsy, but I've beaten my cerebral palsy and I don't mind for my hand. I don't mind my autism, I just sometimes forget things, not that often or don't understand things immediately, not that often too. Only once in 5 months or so. My veins, blue lines running through my body basically, were a little shorter than usual in my right leg. That caused me to walk on my toes for my right leg. I was unable to get the heel to the ground. So with my left leg, I walked normally and fully on the ground, while with my right leg, I just walked on my toes of that foot. At school, kids realising this would always ask me why I was walking like this. I would reply in just a short answer; I was born like this. I've gone through many pain of useless casts and leg braces and even one or two botox injections to get it to the ground, without any benefit. Doctors thought the only solution to this was an operation, but my parents just couldn't make it happen. So in 2016 when I was 10, we visited Turkey in summer break to visit my father's family living there. We also took some of the time to visit a doctor there. The doctor in Turkey said, ameliyat şarttir. An operation is a favor. So, 2 years later in 2018, I finally got operated. When I woke up, I felt my right leg was heavy feeling. When I got back to my room, I lifted up the blanket, and found a tight pink cast wrapped around my leg. I didn't expect that, they didn't tell me they were gonna wrap a cast around afterwards. The nurse said they had done this to keep the extended veins in place for about a month. Just to make sure I was gonna walk on my heel. I was in a wheelchair for about a month or two, after I started learning to walk with those sticks. And eventually with one. Then I had to wear leg braces and get used to them again. I wore them in my childhood as well, this is the first time in years . I haven't been to school for a long while, and I couldn't eat for a few days after getting home even. I was too devastated about the pain i felt. I couldn't sleep, I had to sleep on the couch downstairs, and later on on my matras my mother had brought for me downstairs. Week by week, the pain was slowly reducing by one percent in my thoughts. I cried a lot, but deep down I was more than strong to handle this. These weren't tears of weakness. Secretly, these were plenty tears of joy. My cast was removed, but because of this day I had missed my first meeting event as I call it on my new school. I also had to stay in a therapy place to take therapy. I just was too afraid to walk after I tried walking with my therapist. My heel hurt intense. I thought I would never walk again until everyone forced me to. I again handled it. And finished my last few weeks in elementary school while I was in my wheelchair..successfully, I'd say when I was 11. My first few weeks of middle school were okay. I already memorized everyone's names in my class. Although I was still staying at my therapy place for therapy, I was fine. But one nurse there was teribble. But again, I handled it with every single thing I went through and today, I can walk with no pain, both feet on the ground, many friends made, just one leg brace left, back home, back to normal life with my biggest achievement growing up. My dream, biggest dream, biggest achievement, and only wish in life came true. Thanks to Allah, time and the doctors. I have nothing else I'd want in my life, I'm so grateful. All I've ever wanted is to walk normally and for this operation to take place. Time and Allah shall guide us all to our dreams. I've always been strong to pain, you should be too! I can defeat any kind.

For a second ,just stop and take a quick glance around , what do you see ? You see people ,in a rush ,in chaos ,in a hurry ,in a chase for nothing specific but anything which would help them grab attention from everyone , that being said I find myself on a whole different level then others , for me the biggest achievement means nothing but having a sense of satisfaction by developing my personality and skill set which would give me a better sense of understanding of everything around . So why do I or we need this ? Because I have observed that the people nowadays are more concerned and are constantly under pressure to impress others and figuring out what did they lack in the first place which doesn't makes anyone notice them. And to be honest though ,this is something of an inferiority complex , which people nowadays are infected with , YOU don't need to impress anyone for the sack of attention which might last a couple of seconds or for a word of praise which apparently is of no good use and probably sugar coated. Learn something new , widen your vision of the world , interact with the people around who posses good knowledge and can give you a wise counsel when you need . Do not reveal yourself fully to anyone , don't disclose your innermost secrets to others , let there be a mystery around you , let there be an altar between you and the people , this would get respect ,a dignity which you are worthy of , a sense of accomplishment which towards which you worked hard. Never put efforts to make other people notice you , strive hard to improve yourselves and everyone will come after you . So before I rest my words i can conclude what was the biggest achievement for me , To earn a place in the society which made a mark on everyone because of my honest efforts and a life guided by non compromisable principles which makes the best out of me in every situation.

It may seem like nothing to other people who don't know me. But this July, an almost 10 year lasting dream finally came true: I got my driver's licence, and bought my dream car, a brand new Seat Ibiza. I started applying for my dl in 2008, at the age of 20. Even though the theory lessons at the driving school were pretty good and I've learned a lot, I failed the theoretical test three times. Driving lessons were ok, but even after the 18 mandatory lessons, I still didn't feel confident to pass the main test. The third - and also most important - factor was the money. Taking the driver's licence in Austria is pretty expensive, with all the mandatory lessons, the first aid course, the examination fees and so on, the overall costs could stack up to 2000€. Since I failed the tests multiple times, and also had to take much more driving lessons than the mandatory amount, my savings got less and less and I feared that there soon won't be any money left. The final nail in the coffin was the fact that in early 2009, I moved out of my parent's house and in to my very own flat. All the furniture and household gadgets cost waaay more money than I expected/calculated, so I had to decide wether to spend my life in an empty flat but could drive a car by law, or I would buy more stuff for the flat but stopped driving school entirely. I went with the latter, as you can imagine. Over the last ten years, I mostly didn't miss my licence. Public transportation is excellent in Vienna, and you always find a relatively fast connection from A to B. But there were couple of times where the lack of a driver's licence got me into trouble. My ex-girlfriend was very reliant on her car. She hated the public transport and tried to avoid it at all costs, making her the complete opposite of myself, who had no real alternative but to go by bus/train. Long holiday trips or late night parties were always a reason for heated arguments, since she ALWAYS had to drive the car no matter what. Then all of a sudden, my ex-girlfriend left me in late 2017. What was first an absolute nightmare, turned into something really great for me; Since we had to give up our joint flat, she and I received a good amount of money from the fixtures and fittings of the new tenant. So, there I was, single and with a heck of a lot of money to spare. I decided to overcome my old fears, and applied for the licence - again. During that time, I met my new girlfriend, who also happened to take her driver's licence at the same time. This encouraged me even more, and after just shy of 4 months, I finally got my licence. Long story short, The very moment the examiner said the words “alright, you passed the test. Here's your temporary driver's licence” really felt like a dream come true. My eyes filled with water, and I felt a sudden relieve. Even though I’d repeatedly told myself over the last ten years “you really don't need the licence here in Vienna”, it always felt like something was missing. A few weeks later, I went to a local Seat distributor and got my very first car - a Seat Ibiza. Getting into the car and starting it for the very first time was yet another dream come true moment, since I wanted to own an Ibiza for as long as I can imagine.

Happy New Year! As human beings, achievements are everything in today’s world. It is the single most definitive subject that evaluates our worth, directly or indirectly. But what we fail to realize is that we achieve subtle things even without realizing the same. Making your loved ones’ day a tad better, putting a smile on your parent’s face, pampering them with gifts, making your friends laugh are some of the many examples of the same. Achievements, according to me can be classified as- Personal (which includes families, friends, loved ones, relatives)Academic (School and College/University)Work and experience (Internships and what not!)Hobbies and extra-curricular activitiesSince childhood, I have had an obsession with collecting certificates. Some of them are- School and College level (First one!)         2. Internships        3. Creative and Content Writing            4. But none of these even come close to- i. The time when I gifted my Mother a Book, saris, earrings and a watch from my earnings as a content writer. (I have been doing freelance writing for the past 6+ years since I was in class 12) ii. The time when I gifted my father a watch, some nice shirts from the same earnings as a content writer. iii. The time when I gifted my close relatives something of their choice after I secured my first job. (The gifts were not so expensive, but from the expressions on their faces, I could say they were happy. That is all that matters!) iv. The time when I gifted my grandmother a sari. She smiled sweetly through her gums and disappearing teeth and gave me a kiss. I’ll cherish that moment forever! v. The time when I gifted a few of the house-helpers, who have been helping with domestic work since I was a baby, saris. They were overjoyed! In the end, it all boils down to the persons whom you care about the most. Because if they aren’t present, you will not get any joy out of accomplishing something. Cheers! ~Biswadeep

I’m tempted to say “made a couple of beautiful children”, because they really do rock. But it’s not a particularly distinctive answer to the question. There’s an irony to my other answer — the thing that I think of as my greatest achievement isn’t visible anywhere… it doesn’t show up in my bank account or on the Internet, there’s no monument or blazing Broadway lights or applause of the crowd associated with this achievement, nobody stands back in awe when I enter the room, preceded by my reputation. In a sense, I am the only person who knows that anything was achieved or understands what the achievement is or what it meant. So that’s the kind of achievement that makes people roll their eyes and hold up an “L” between thumb and forefinger. The achievement is just this: I am able to be myself, with reasonable reliability. It’s not 100% “solved”, it’s more like a camera that goes in and out of focus a lot, but most of the time, the focus is pretty good. So that might not seem like much, but being a slow learner, it took me over 40 years to get that sorted out. The serious work started when I was about 15, and things really shaped up when I was about 55. So 40 years to produce an achievement that nobody can even see or assess or praise. Pretty cool, huh? Cue the fireworks! If there’s any benefit for others out of that achievement, it might be that I think I understand the road to this destination better than most: I’ve spent enormous time and energy studying the obstacles and dead-ends along the way, I’ve had to solve the same puzzles over and over again until I felt like I could do it in my sleep, I’ve been wrong about details more times than can be counted, and had to recognize the error the hard way — by suffering. That understanding of the road is potentially shareable, so that’s a high priority for me — I see other people struggling with those same puzzles sometimes, and my memory sucks but it’s good enough to recall how painful that can be. Anyway. I’ve got maybe 20–30 years left, I think. It seems like a shame that it took so much of my life just to get to the starting line, but at least that’s checked off the list finally. Now I’m interested to see what life is actually like, when it isn’t about “who am I?”

The standard answer, of course, is “my kids.” After them…. Back in 1992, the Internet opened to the public, a group of us started The Center for Civic Networking to do demonstration projects that applied the Internet to public purposes (read “electronic town meetings” - though we quickly ventured into other areas). As part of our first project - an electronic town meeting in Cambridge, MA - as part of a broader, community-wide visioning exercise - we quickly discovered that most people in Cambridge, outside the university community & some high tech employees, didn’t have Internet access. So… we set out to provide public access in the Cambridge Public Library. At the time, the only Internet access, in public libraries, anywhere, were a few “Freenet” installations - basically bulletin board systems with limited connectivity, installed by outside groups (“can we install one of these in the library?”) - with librarians only discovering later that people expected lots of hand holding. We (well, I) proceeded to write a grant proposal to the Apple Library of Tomorrow Program (great losses when Apple shut it down, and when it’s director, Steve Cisler died). Apple gave us a gaggle of top-end Macs, which we proceeded to place in the main Cambridge Library, as well as several additional libraries on Cape Cod. It didn’t hurt that the Library Director was on our Board. Continental Cablevision provided cable modem service (we were their alpha site). Central to our effort was extensive planning with the library staff (down to details of where to put the screens to insure privacy), setting up navigational & local information screens (as well as content related to the community visioning project), training library staff, setting up training sessions for the public, and holding the requisite ribbon-cutting ceremony with politicians & the press in attendance. We were the first public library, anywhere in the world, to provide true, high-speed, Internet access as a routine library service. And then I got to write the only book I know of on planning & implementing library-based Internet access. I set out to find someone to pay for publishing our final report, and ended up writing a book for the American Library Association (ALA) Press. I even made a little money on the book - who know that the ALA had a book club - the book ended up as a monthly selection that went to librarians across the country. Now, computers & Internet access would have shown up in libraries, regardless of our efforts. But we were first, helped to point the way, and perhaps helped some folks avoid some wrong turns. When I think back on the past 45 years or so, I see a number of bigger, more complex projects, perhaps with greater impact - in both smaller & larger roles. But when I ask myself what am I proudest of - I always come back to the library project.

The highest achievement that I’ve achieved in my lifetime is my job as a computer consultant in Transcanada Pipelines. It was my first job and the only formal job I have had in my life. Therefore, I would consider it as my highest achievement. After graduation from SAIT, I was accepted by a small management consultant company. I didn’t know that I was going to be assigned to Transcanada to do 4D programming and consulting. Honestly speaking, I was very nervous. What I did was to grasp every minute to go over a 4D bible book. I used 3 months to finish that book and felt more confident. My supervisor was very nice to me. He designed a series of applications and I finished them very well. He was very satisfied with me. After finishing this training, I was assigned to become further familiar with 4D applications which Transcanada used as a tester. After 3 months, I was transferred to Department of Transportation to start my independent working as a consultant. I maintained several core applications for them and dealt with their employees at the same time. I did very well and finished my task on time. My supervisor was a 30 year old lady who was responsible for database part. Her name was Debby Yuen. Is she still in Transcanada? She was very loose to me since she fully trusted me. She did not know much 4D. The head of this department Paul Rushton was also very satisfied with my job and planned to give me on call work to maintain the database. I forgot why I did not do it later. I was becoming more and more nearer to them. But unfortunately, I had to go back to do my maternal leave. After half a year, I went back and did one month. My husband decided to let me quit. Everything was very smooth and I did this job very easily. Now when I recalled back, I was actually little scared since if I messed up the applications, the Transcanada would kill me. It was their billing application and other some that I forgot. Although it was not a high programming job, but I still considered it as my highest achievements. It was my first job and would be my last job? Hope I can have another IT job that is waiting for me. Thanks for reading.

My house was five miles from the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta, a 100-square mile network of rivers and sloughs. Being a water rat, I was itching to get out and partake.  My dog at the time was a 45-pound Aussie: no fitting him in a kayak. Had to be a canoe. Purchased a Coleman Classic off Craigslist.  I won’t tell you how hoisting it up on the roof of my SUV resulted in it slipping sideways and shearing off the rear view mirror for a $375 bill (the canoe was $60 with paddles). And I won’t tell you how many marinas I called for storage space before I found one that would take me in for my requested fee of $20 a month (marinas expect to make $200–500/boat berth.) But find one I did. Now here’s the problem: the delta (originally swamp) was formed mostly by Chinese laborers, who built levees, then drained the land and formed the sloughs. The “islands” are lower than the water level. They sell boat caddies that attach to canoes, to make them portable, so a person can stand behind and push it like a wheelbarrow. I decided I could make my own out of an old kids bike trailer that was taking up space in the garage. Carriers fit in the middle of the canoe, so the canoer only has to wrangle half the boat weight. My problem was only the nose of the canoe fit into my kids’ bike trailer, so I had to virtually lift the entire weight of the canoe (about 70 pounds) and push it uphill over the top of the levee. Then I had to turn the boat and walk backwards, so the boat wouldn’t just go shooting off into the water on the downhill side. I used to work up quite a sweat with this maneuver, all the while congratulating myself I was boating for $20 a month! Darcy the dog (named after Mr. Darcy of Sense and Sensibility fame), watched from the passenger seat of the car, with a concerned expression, or maybe it was weary resignation, like wouldn’t it be nice to be owned by a human of normal intelligence?  This picture is actually of a sailboat, but Darcy is wearing the same dubious expression. One day, after I sweated my heavy canoe up the levee, raced ahead and then guided it down to the boat ramp, a Vietnamese fisher woman who had watched my antics with fascination, said breathlessly, “You are strong woman!” She was nearly unable to contain peals of laughter. I invested in a regular boat carrier after that.

I'm a crazy, crazy MUNner and this is a story from my beginning days of MUNning. We were simulating the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) with the agenda of the Rehabilitation of Syrian Refugees. I was the delegate of Lebanon for the same, a strong country on the agenda. After a week of good research, I finally sat up to write my Position Paper. A Position Paper is the essence of all your research. Though not mandatory, promoted, and recommended, submitting it prior to your conference can earn you real brownie points. A day before the conference, I spent 6 hours on my laptop slogging my head off, compiling that two-page document, putting in details after scanning hundreds of reports, laws, amendments, protocols, and synopsis. It was a daunting task. At 2:10 am, I was almost done. A 30-minute work and I'd get to hit the bed. My eyes were already blood red with all the strain. And my laptop decided to freeze. After uncountable attempts, it did not budge. I cursed myself for not saving my work. The only option left was to shut the laptop down. The document I put my soul in, would be lost. I sat staring at the frozen screen for more than an hour. Finally decided to put it and myself to sleep because a sleepless night would harm my performance at the conference further. Shit had happened. I started to become unsure of whether or not to participate. I had to leave by 9 in the morning. I thought I should just make an excuse and sleep it off. Then it hit me. I'd already incurred a big loss. But here, if I lose my courage, I'll be a real loser. With a brave plan in my head, I put myself to sleep. At 6 am, I sat up, opened the laptop, to do the Position Paper all over again. It may sound an utterly unpractical decision, but was also the best option I had. In a record time of 95 minutes, I made the WHOLE THING again. Yes, AGAIN. At this point, I had drained myself of all the energy I had. Yet, the fact that I could do the document all over again gave me a feeling of invincibility and I lasted all day long participating successfully. I went on to receive the Best Speaker at the conference and also got recommended for Vice-Chair in an upcoming conference. The loss of the document was a major setback, but being able to rise over it and put myself together was my biggest victory here. The trophy I was awarded with was merely a cherry on the cake. Whenever I think of this incident in my life, now, I get major motivation. “If I've done this, I can do anything!!! ” TRULY A VICTORY OVER FAILURE!

Teaching high school students. Yes I consider this as my biggest one because I had always avoided teaching this group ever since I got my B.Ed. . In my mind, high school students loud, disrespectful, and full of drama. I was so surprised when my principal assigned me to teach this level because I usually had the pre-uni students. She had warned me that some kids could be a handful but some were ok. I will never forget my first day walking to the class and saw them. I felt like I wanted to freeze everything and set the clock to the end of the class. My first two terms were rough with the kids because I got angry all the time and they showed their resistance towards me. But as time went by, I realized that these kids were actually nice. They wanted to be friends with all teachers including me. So I opened up to them a little bit. I played along with their jokes . They liked it when I laughed with them or managed to make me laugh. I like it too because I realized that this way, the kids started warming up to me. I sometimes pull a prank on them too and they responded positively. Apparently when I’m relax, they listen to me more. Our relationship got better. I didn’t get angry as much as I was the first time. I tried to listen to them and use a more sympathetic tone when I talked to. They paid more attention in the class. Weeks ago, the female students were playing a game close to the teachers’ office and I briefly joined as I was walking towards the room. One of them suddenly hugged me so tight and said, “Miss Cindy, I love you.” I hugged her back and said, wholeheartedly, “I love you too.” Years ago I would say “no” if someone asked me whether I wanted to teach high school students or not. I’m glad that my principal assigned me and I took the chance, proving myself wrong.

Q: What is your biggest achievement in life? It might be the resolute solving of the nature of existence. The finding of the final and complete answer to “What is the universe made of, exactly?”. It has always been the “exactly” that has caused the problem. I don’t know that I have. But suspect it might be so, and with some good reasons. Might be a while till I know for sure.  If not that, then I am not sure what the next biggest is. I like unique accomplishments. Like, winning the first 18 games of lawn bowling I ever played, including games against opponents with significantly more experience, and considerable motivation and desire to beat me if they at all possibly could. See. I joined the sport in my early 20s. My parents were in a club, and it looked like good fun. When younger, I had been an alley bowler. In leagues. 5-pin for a couple of years, then 10 pin for 7 or 8. During which time, I got pretty adept. Becoming a scratch bowler. (average of 180 or so). As well as having played soccer for many years, and billiards quite passionately since my late teens.  See. Having been born “slenderish”, and growing lanky through my early years, I was never what one would call naturally athletic. Some might have called me a nerd, or geek. With some justification. But I am also very analytical, and observant. I notice things. Can “see” things. Turns out in a little more detail than many. And I am also competitive. Or was, more so than now, when I was younger. And so, with sports, I would analyze. Look for tricks. Advantages. In soccer, I learned to curve the ball with some accuracy. And then later, when my muscles caught up to my length, I learned how better to use my body to apply force to the ball, and because a wicked hard kicker. In 10-pin bowling, I bought myself a custom bowling ball. Well, a couple, actually. The second one, my “for life” bowling ball (not that I bowl hardly ever anymore), I put research into. I bought a ball specifically for alley grip. A dull black rubbery surface. And then for the hole drilling, I had it done at the extreme offset from the center of the weight block allowed by the rules. (10-pin balls have a small block of denser material on the side where the finger holes will be drilled, so the loss of material will not cause too much lop-sidedness. There are rules about where, and how many, and how wide, and how deep, you can have your ball drilled for your grip. Mine are at the maximum right side. Putting the balls overall center of gravity, just off-center by a tiny amount. This affects its ability to curve or hook when thrown.) Well. Back to lawn bowling. Lawn bowls have a built in bias. One side is curved differently than the other. There is a “small side”, and a “large side”. So when it is running fast, it will tend to “stand up” onto its maximum radius and run straight. As it slows down, it will lean over more and more towards the small side, in a curve that decreases in radius as the bowl slows further.  So the possible paths will look something like below, one side is shown, it is reversible.  Once an end is underway, it quickly gains aspects that relate to billiards or curling. Combinations and caroms. Reflections and deflections. Transfer of kinetic energy though multiple collisions at various angles.  It is true that some of my earlier games were against newer or less skilled players. But not at all, all of them. In around game 5 or 6 the Tuesday night men's league began, and being early in the season more leads than skips were showing up. So on the second night, the team selector chose to promote me to skip temporarily. This caused a bit of a ruckus. Apparently it as a position of honour and was desired. and several elder members with several years experience, who were designated leads, objected to my being made skip on my second night. One gent, who later became a good friend, once he got over what went down that night, was the loudest objector. And also got made a skip. And by chance got drawn against me. He was a fine man. An ex-fighter pilot. (this was back in the 80s). Well. He had made it clear he intended to win. And I, very much wished to not have my position questioned based on my age, and experience, rather than my ability. And thought perhaps they could have handled their objections a little more tactfully. I think it fair to say, I too saw “motivated”. This sounds a little “braggy”. But it really wasn’t fair. I was, yes, inexperienced at lawn bowling. But my accumulated experiences and interests had really turned me into a “programmed lawn bowling machine” that had never been used for that purpose. My billiards gave me the ability to know what would occur if the “head” was hit from a certain angle with a certain force. As surely as I could spell my own name. And the single focus in 10 pin bowling is the delivery of a ball over a distance, with a hook, to a specific millimeter or finer if one is attempting to convert a split. And the ability to throw 16 pounds hard, and dead straight on demand. For when that is what needed. So then, come to an end in a game of lawn bowling. Maybe sitting down a couple. You have options… knock a couple out, end up a few up. Draw in, cut the two and earn one. Or you send a zinger straight up the throat, and blast the head to smitherines… bowls and the jack landing where you intend, predict, or where they will. That is called “the runner”. In the right hands, it is an atomic bomb that a lawn bowler can drop anytime the situation is not optimal. From alley-bowling to lawn-bowling, the transfer of the ability to do that, through very hard, very straight, to a very specific point, is pretty much 100%. Not much calibration or adjustment needed. It just works. And in alley bowling, you tend to be able to hit a single pin about 98 times out of 100 when at the scratch bowler level. Which then applied to lawn bowling… the two leads take turn about, throwing their 4 bowls. Then it is the skips turn. Now there is the “jack”… it is the “target”… the goal is, after each team has thrown 8 bowls, give a point to the bowl that is closest to the team it belongs to, and then another for each of their bowls that is closer than the best of the other teams bowls. So the skip steps up. The situation is either: up 1 to 4 bowls for the end (1 round of play), or down 1 to 4 bowls. With the 8 arranged around the jack. In theory where the Skip asked the lead to put them. The skips then roll their 4 bowls, turn about. Each time I stepped up, I held one of 4 atomic bombs, if I felt like it. (insert a lot of evil grins, and buahahahahas). If we had a couple close, but one of theirs was closer, there was the snipe option. If they were sitting a few, but there was a line to the jack… no problem, nail the jack and take it with you. They go from up a few to down one or more. And have nothing close to try to turn it back to several in their favour. (This is also quite disheartening for the other team, going from sitting pretty to down and without reason for hope.) Oh this retelling is starting to feel a little evil. Because, admittedly, ego, youth, objection to being objected to, I did get my lawn-bowl “dukes” up. And I did pummel said vociferous objector. Some 21 to 1 or something like that. (Poor guy). I should also admit. That while I had fair good fortune, entering tournaments, the many that happen around the province for cash prizes and a very nice day out… I also entered the official pyramid of competition, the “club-regional-provincial-national” yearly setup done annually. A few times. And got my own handed right back to me on many many occasions!! Years of good fun.  But yes. On the list of “proudest accomplishments”, I think I like that one, because I figure it is probably relatively unique. I figure not too many people, even the world champion lawn bowlers, won their first 18. Some. Maybe. But not many. :-D If I am wrong about having solved existence… at least I won my first 18 games of lawn bowling. lol. Made a few kids, and performed some miracles in IT in between.

Well, my achievement is different from others. It's not about money making job or owning a luxury Villa or car .  Look at the above picture , this was my life five years back in 2015 . I was diagnosed with kidney failure at a very young age of 18 and was ungergoing regular dialysis session . I was totally bedridden and became so weak that I couldn't even walk and I used to have frequent attacks ( i can't even explain that feeling in words here ) and because of that I was admitted in ICU many times. While most of my friends were making their career and Enjoying their life , I was struggling to survive every day . I was physically , mentally and emotionally broken but luckily I had my parents to support me and they kept motivating me to live. I had almost lost all the hopes to live because I was fed up with dialysis session which were so painful. I still remember my fistula surgery , how painful it was !!!!! Also, I wasn't even allowed to drink water. Can you all imagine my suffering….a young boy who had so many dreams about his life was hooked up to dialysis machines in the hospital . I am very grateful to my mommy ❤️ as she decided to donate her kidney to me and after two painful years , I underwent kidney transplant surgery and it literally changed my life in such a good and positive way. I finally found hope to live my life and now I am living my life to the fullest.  It's been almost four years since I underwent kidney transplant surgery. I am living a healthy life again. Fullfilling my goals and dreams. I love travelling so much . So , the very first thing I did was to go on a solo travelling around the world after my surgery. I have travelled to 13 countries and counting. My dream is to travel the world.  This is me now. From struggling each day to survive to living my life to the fullest. I have come a long way and so proud of myself ❤️  For me living a healthy and happy life is the greatest achievement in life . I am living a healthy life by God's grace and I am very grateful and thankful to my mommy for gifting me her kidney. Much love to all and take care of yourself.

I believe my biggest achievement till date has been "Getting out of my comfort zone and pursuing my dream no matter how weird, stupid, disturbing the situations had been" I always loved writing but somehow just like all Indian children are treaded on the same path I was put into Engineering. And trust me I never had the nerve or the confidence to tell my family that Engineering was not my thing. By my second year, I started participating into events and polished my skills. By the end of fourth year I had started a blog, started writing on Quora and was reading literally 3 books in a week. There was a marked improvement in my vocabulary and thought procedure. The battle began thereafter.I read about Startups in India on Quora and I thought this will be a place where I will get to learn and do the work I want. My parents wanted me to join Syntel, an IT firm whose offer letter had already came. A long battle of trying to convince them, fight, argue, cry, continued for one month. I did not budge and at one moment I declared that I am going to Mumbai to join a startup that has sent me it's offer letter.Seeing how adamant I was about it, my parents agreed half heartedly. For the first time I was stepping out of my home. I has never done an air journey. Trust me I did not even know what to do at the airport. I landed in Mumbai, started living alone.It's only when you start living alone that you realize there are so many things to take care of. From your clothes, food, house to electricity bills, bank works, taxations.I knew nothing. Plus the work at my job was also very new. I could write but Digital marketing is a very different field all together.Being emotionally independent, travelling alone, taking care of yourself and learning everything was going parallel for me. I became like a combination of filter and sponge.  I lost track of time, I was learning and learning. Things were messy. I was out for the first time. I did not know how to conduct myself. What to say and what not to. Whom to trust and who not to. I made a lot of mistakes. When i say "a lot" that means a lot. It was a struggle. Then last month I again hit rock bottom. I left my first job. I wanted to do so much more so I started applying in startups for the role of Digital Marketing Strategist. I interviewed at 8 startups an gladly got offer letters from all of them. But that wasn't an easy task as well. I was very very keen on working for a specific one-  WebEngage. While on my way to the interview of this startup, I met an accident. My trousers were torn, my knees were bleeding and all but all I had in mind was that the CEO might not be available after that and it would be a disrespect of his time. I bought another pair of trousers, washed my injuries and went limping for the interview. (it was hilarious, I looked like a run away kid) I got my offer letter that very day after the interview. I had a strange medical reaction that very night at 3 am. I was also on a nine day fast. For a moment I thought why is everything happening at once. 15 days passed. These entire 7 months changed me as a person on so many levels. I became cautious, I became patient, I understood that life is not always fair but I also understood no matter what we should be grateful for what we have. I joined my new job, new challenges have come. But life should be full of challenges because it doesn't shine in comfort. Life is never as difficult as we think it will be and every good or bad time passes away. I feel proud when I look back in time and compare the timid, underconfident girl who would not even go to the market alone to this girl who is staying alone in a city , earning and living one heck of a life. It is a major achievement for me. Battling clinical depression was also one. But this one strengthened me enough to tackle anything. Just remember one thing:- REFUSE TO QUIT, NO MATTER WHAT!!!

Biggest achievement huh ? Cool. Opens achievement section of the brain. Nothing found. Searches again. Prrf. Nothing. What now dude?! Closes achievement section. Suffers in silence. Cries in the corner. I don't know the meaning of achievement. Shit load of money, fame, lots of parties, superhot chicks, thousands of social media followers, ultracool cars, a private jet, and a villa in the coast of Hawaii. If this is what achievement means, man I'm screwed. I've got nothing. Damn. My whole life was a lie. Gets his senses back. Opens life section.Nice. That being said, I've achieved some simple things in life to smile about. Ok this is pure bragging. Go on. Read at your own risk. I've managed to make exactly 4.5 friends on whom I can bank upon at any point of my life. They'll be there for sure. Worth more than a billion dollar villa.I was a known face in college. Been a serial topper and hey, it's all about prize money and the attention. Nerd mode? Hell no. Last bench, novels, Quizzing, stageshows, and everything else which had the word “fun” attached to it. No, my notes weren't famous at all.I'm a polyglot. Yes, I consider this a bloody achievement. Comon talk to me ;)Managed to come out alive after a trek from a friggin forest in the western ghats. No deal big? Let's add, rain, darkness, snakes, elephants, leeches, broken butt and minus humans. How about that ?Conquering my fear of public speaking. Long back during school days it was a nightmare. Now it's just pure bliss.Conquering my fear of the unknown. 5 days at Airforce selection board and I came back a new human. One of the best days of my twenties.Transition from an introvert to an extrovert. Don't ask me how, but whatever happened, happened like magic. I don't know. I love this.From a tiny-whiny weak kid to a fit and healthy dude. This one felt epic. To all those losers who picked a fight with me at school, come here, I gotta talk now.Opening up with people without the fear of being judged. You guessed it right, I'm talking about dates, crushes and midnight tea talks.Learning and mastering the art of not giving a shit. I don't know whether redbull gives you wings, but this surely does. Flying mode activated.Quitting the job which sucked the peace out of me. 3 jobs in 1.5 years. Hell, yea.Conquering my fear of drowning. 2 months of training and I swim like a shark now. Water water everywhere.Learning one of the best things in life, cooking. Thanks mom. Come home, I'll make you a feast that you'll never forget.Hunting down each and every desire in my yearly bucket list. MorganFreeman mode.Talking about career, I've been lucky enough to land in a decent paying job at a PSU which takes care of my bread and butter for now.Last one, I've got a platform to quench my thirst for writing. Turning into a decent known face within 5 months on Quora, this is friggin awesome. Loving every moment of it.I can brag all night , but I've got a vacation to plan. So yea, bubye for now. Grateful. Blessed. Peace. P.s - Wondering what the hell “4.5 friends” is? Well, 4 complete souls, and that one dude whom you're not sure about, but he's a fantastic soul to hang around with.

Answering this question runs perilously close to self-aggrandizement and narcissism, and I would ordinarily eschew its like, but I was just ruminating on this subject today while cleaning & reorganizing my studio, and the weird coincidence intrigued me. Without too much self-promotion or self-congratulations, then, permit me to attest that I have lived the life I have wanted to live: full of unexpected choices, eccentric detours, & prodigious achievements— playing music (European classical & Balinese gamelan); inventing and patenting alternative energy system devices; going to sea on a commercial fishing boat (on which I eventually became the skipper); volunteering as a teacher in a public high school; making artwork (& winning awards); making movies; being a published author several times over; designing and building elaborate landscape gardens— the list is really rather satisfying, as an objective measure of a curriculum vitae, or lifework. How interesting in my own mind, then, that these were not the achievements that loom largest in my memory or imagination. In 2007 I helped my adopted Ukrainian family start a small business that has launched them (and several of their close friends) from a humble— sometimes arduous— lower-middleclass existence to a solidly upper middle class life (I continue as the CFO of this boutique company, but I must give credit where credit is due: my partner is brilliant is managing our plan, and both she & her husband have been tireless in doing the hard work). I think I’ve been a good friend, & that seems like an achievement. Even more so, though, I've been a good son. My stepfather died in 2012, leaving my 67 year old mom feeling rather adrift and irrelevant in her own life. My pop was younger than my mom, & I had always assumed I would end up caring for him in his old age, but our plans seldom work out the way we expect. I have a brother, but he lives in the bottom of a whiskey bottle, so there really wasn’t anyone else, though this point should not be mistaken for reluctance on my part. My mom is 72 now, and spends half her year with me in St.Petersburg, Florida, in a “house” I built for her attached to my own, giving her a sense of independence essential to her well-being, simultaneous with a rich family life that has largely ameliorated her feelings of loneliness (she spends the other half of the year in the house she shared with my pop, in a lovely meadow in New York State’s Catskill Mountains, where I visit her in the summer). My mom has been— and continues to be— a truly great mother, and she is just too young for her life to be over yet (we have a longevity gene in our family that may see her into her nineties). It pleases me to have helped her find the next chapter of her life: she deserves it, & I think my pop would be proud of me, and that’s an achievement I don’t mind claiming…

My kids … “Oh man, not another one of these.” I know children are a great achievement, but one that many people share. My greatest achievement is not having my kids, but being able to be the parent they deserve to have.  God, just look at those adorable little pumpkins! Look how happy they are because they got to see one of their most recent favorite characters from a movie. Look how happy they were to go to the fair that they didn't even know they were going to. Yep, it's easy to see the thrill in this picture, but what you don't see is the mom behind the camera silently wiping tears from her eyes because she was able to do this for them. You don't see the two hundred dollars that was pinched painfully that entire month so they could have this moment. You don't see the father standing off to the side and you don't see the look that was shared between mom and dad that wordlessly agreed — this was all worth it! See, before we had children we were both addicts. I don't often include him in my answers because that is his story, but we are both well aware that had we not changed, we would not have our children today. Change … such an easy word to say but such a hard thing to do. We clawed and fought our way through hell together in the trenches of addiction and we carried eachother out. . It was never easy, but moments like this …  Remind me just how big of an achievement it really was. Words cannot express how fucking grateful I am to be able to share these moments with my kids.

Surviving the last 5 years, and having coped mentally with the last couple of months. For context, I have severe mental health issues which were initially recognised 5 years ago. I have tried to commit suicide more times than I can count and have come across so many negative, judgemental people as well as fought with the horrifically underfunded mental health system. I've been left to languish in the community because nobody knew where to look for an appropriate bed, or been told that while I need a bed, they don't have any. The last two months I've been fighting with unspecified, undiagnosable GI issues. I've had a dietician recommend a nasogastric (feeding) tube because she considers me to be at a very high risk of malnutrition. But despite 3 admissions and 5 ED attendances for this problem alone, despite the fact that I'm so dizzy I'm using a wheelchair to get around outside, despite that all my benefits this month went on taxis and other expenses directly or indirectly related to these issues, despite all of that I'm rarely self harming and am, by my standards at least, stable. Sometimes just getting through is massively underrated. Sometimes it's ignored that getting out of bed each morning and, in my case, fighting dizziness, nausea, vomiting, brain fog, abdominal pain, joint pain, migraines and a multitude of other things, can be the biggest achievement at all. I am immensely proud of the most fundamental thing of all: being alive. Because unless I can manage that I'm never going to fix or deal with everything else wrong with my life.

I have learned that success is to be measured not so much by the position that one has reached in life as by the obstacles which he has had to overcome while trying to succeed. ~ Booker T. Washington I’ve always been an active child in my school. I was always class monitor . Always aced my exams. But, in 10th class my health started to deteriorate. I would be having fever one day to some really bad cold other day. I would miss my school for 2–3 months together. I got hospitalized thrice in my 10th standard. Same went on in my 11th standard. I used to get so ill. One day fever, another day some digestive issue then allergies on my eyes, in which big bumps would grow up. I would always feel so helpless. My classmates used to make fun of me, how I was always sick. This used to hurt me so much! I still remember a coversation between me and my (so-called) friend. (My health got better and I started going to school regularly. I went to play basketball as I always wanted to be in some kind of sport. After giving trial , I got selected.) Then, this is how the conversation went like- Friend - Oh Hi Ashmeet. How are you feeling now? I heard you got hospitalised. Me - I’m feeling much better now. Just came after giving basketball trial. Friend - Basketball WHAT? Vaise toh tu hmesha bimaar rehti hai, school toh dikhti nahin hai aur ab tujhe basketball khelni hai?? (Translation - Most of the times you are sick and can’t be even seen in school and now you want to play basketball?) This conversation made me feel so bad about myself! I felt like nobody understands that even if I’m sick, I still want to play and enjoy. Afterall, nobody gets sick intentionally! Then, I passed my 11th with 70% marks and was shattered because I used to be in the top-scorer’s always. In 12th, my health was more or less same. But, this time I affirmed to myself that I will take care of my health no matter what. I took the whole responsibility of my health and didn’t depend on anybody. With grace of god, my health got better. Boards were approaching. My class teacher motivated me to put my heart and soul and give my 110% in these exams. I was also filled up with all the bad experiences of the past. All the taunts of friends and scoldings by teachers. I gave my exams and finally results came .  I was second stream topper and left behind all those who used to taunt me and made me worthless! Everything in life depends on how we perceive it. My biggest achievement indeed, is proving myself, not to anybody else but to my own self because I know my worth and capabilities more than anybody else! Only I know, how I felt when anyone would make fun of me. I MADE MYSELF PROUD!🙏🏻 Thankyou for reading .😊

When I was a kid I played little league baseball. I played left field. During a final championship game we were winning by 1 point in the bottom of the 9th. There were two men on base with two outs, and the other teams best hitter at bat. My friend Joey played center field, he was a good guy but a little nervous disposition, anyway, the batter hits a high fly ball out to center field, I could see Joey was scared to death. I start running across the field to back him up, but I'm too late the ball comes down hits Joey's glove and bounces in the air going behind him, I take a huge dive across the field my glove extended, I hit the ground in a cloud of dust, when I look in my glove there is the ball. I made the catch, batter is out and we won the game. I was a freaking hero. All our teams parents in the bleachers are cheering, the team including coach Tom run out on the field and are hugging me and patting me on the back and cheering me. After the game coach Tom treated us to a huge pizza party at Pizza hut. He presented me with the trophy, which sat in my bedroom for years after, well the trophy is long gone today but that moment in time still brings a smile to my face, whenever I think of it, it really was the greatest achievement of my life. As an adult I've done a lot of cool things, I've helped people, I saved two people in a car accident, but that one moment was still the best.

On July 8, 2016, I was honored with the Genesis Home Run for Life award in front of 4,000 cheering fans during my hometown’s minor league baseball game. Genesis, my local healthcare provider, recognizes a few individuals each year who have relentlessly fought and overcome their medical illnesses. I was nominated and walked the bases during the top of the fourth inning while my entire community was chanting my name. The 360-foot walk around the bases was an extremely emotional moment for me because exactly one year prior, I was completely wheelchair-bound from a spinal cord injury, known as Transverse Myelitis, that I had endured. This honorable recognition was well worth the hundreds of grueling therapy appointments, thousands of sit-to-stands, and hours on the leg bike that helped me trade in my wheelchair for my own two feet. Here are some images from my big day:  I am standing in the striped shirt. Everyone of my supporters was wearing a Team Kale t-shirt.  The stadium was packed, and I can say I was very nervous that I might trip and fall.  My elementary school crush. Funny story, in the fifth grade on Valentine’s day, everyone was passing around the candy they brought. Later that afternoon, I noticed a letter in my candy bag, and it was from this girl—Zoe. I was so happy because the letter asked if I wanted to be her boyfriend. However, I was so shy and nervous that I never responded to her! Not even to this day! Damn, I was dumb.  THE SQUAD Ultimately, I had a tremendous time and was extremely honored to have been recognized in front of my entire community.

I think my biggest achievement is the way I fought with my depression and came out of it on my own. It all started when I was in my 3rd year of engineering. I had a breakup and it affected my professional and personal life. It started with my breakup and from there, things started taking ugly turns. After that, I failed in engineering, my grades went low. I stopped going for CAT coaching. I lost my confidence. The same year I lost my grandfather and it was a set back too. I started drinking and smoking. I was under immense pressure and depression. I was so depressed that one day in anger I shaved my head. I was studying on scholarship. I was in the college hostel(It was free for me), when my father came to know about my situation, he made sure that I move out of the hostel. He even got me a new smartphone so I can get over my depression. I belong to a lower-middle-class family and when I realized how much my parents care for me, I understood how I am spoiling my life. That day, I promised my self that I will work hard and come out of this hell, which I only created. I stopped going for my CAT classes and focused on Job. I cleared my exams and completed my engineering with 7.8 CGPA. I got a decent job in an MNC. I worked hard and saved 25K INR which I gifted to my parents for their 25th Wedding Anniversary. I quit smoking and now I drank only occasionally. Later I joined the gym and started working out regularly. In 2016, I came to Bangalore. I promised myself to have a fresh start. Now its been two years I am in Bangalore. I am doing good and I hope to do it better. I have achieved quite a few things after coming to Bangalore like I fell in love again and trust me love can happen twice. I bought my first bike with my savings and the feeling was awesome. Worked hard on my fitness, followed diet and reduced about 15kgs. Started My YouTube channel named Saddaa India and started taking Quora seriously. Recently I crossed, 200 subscribers on YouTube and 1K followers on Quora. I know maybe for some of you these achievements are not considerable, but I believe in small steps, one step by one. I am trying my best and I hope to get best out of me in future. That's my new bike: Suzuki INTRUDER  This is me in 2016, I gained weight after finishing my studies.  And this is me in 2017.  Here is the picture of my Aadhar card for which I applied a few days later after shaving my head.  I hope now you guys believe in me. Never Give Up, Trust me your time will come. Always remember that good thing takes time. Just follow your heart and start enjoying the journey of your life. Don't kill yourself, Kill the Depression If anyone of you is going through such depression, please feel free to reach out. You can text me and share your problems. I know it's not gonna change something but trust me if you talk about it you will feel relieved. Just let it go. Keep reading and Keep Learning. Thank you so much for your time. See you soon. Manish Raj Srivastav (मनीष राज श्रीवास्तव)

At 24, my life until now is full of adventure. I was born in a low middle-class family in Patna, Bihar. My mom and dad were working so they don't have so much time either me or for my brother. When I was around 5,6 year old, I like to play cricket very much and roaming around my neighbourhood for the guys who can play cricket with me. My dad didn't find it right they might think (ki main biggar jagua ) because my locality, wasn't good. Then they took the decision to send me to a cricket academy so that I can play and utilized my energy in the right place. I still remember I was in class 3rd on the time when I took admission into the Academy after that I was doing really good in cricket played state for few years for different age groups and on that time Bihar has affiliation issue so players have to switch states if they want to play for state and explore opportunities in a bigger level. So I decided that after my 10th I will leave my state for better opportunities. Due to involvement in cricket, I was not able to study and I did not want to study. I wanted to play and chill. In my 8th standard, I got 49% marks and fail in maths  The idea behind sharing my 8th standard mark sheet is to tell that I was so bad at my studies. Then in 2011, I came to Delhi after my 10th examination. After coming to Delhi and playing local cricket for 1.5 year my coach refer me to appear in U-16 state trail. Fortunately I got selected in U-16 state camp but due to domicile issue. I was kicked out of the camp. Now 12 board is very important for everyone and crucial for the college admission process. *This is the point where I have to think what to do* Cricket? OR Study? Cricket is full of probability (everything or nothing). My family financial condition was not well I have chosen study to at least give my family a better life. Here some of my cricketing achievement. This was my image on google.The other one with the ex-chief minister of Bihar Rabri Devi.  ISHAN Kishan U-19 INDIA CAPTAIN AND MUMBAI INDIAN OPENER was my childhood friend. We have played together for many years and due to affiliations problem he went to Jharkhand and I went to Delhi.  In September 2012 I have decided to take my study seriously and left Cricket forever. I had 5 months to prepare for my 12 Examination. I devoted all my time to study and start preparing for my 12th. I scored 79% in my 12th with self-study after that I did maths honours from Delhi University and completed with distinction on the same subject in which I failed in class 8th. After my graduation, I went to Hansraj college for my masters in operation research only a few top colleges in India offer this course. In master, I got the placement with the package of 7.5 LPA and currently working for the organization. My class topper in school is still searching for a job and all. I am not demoralising anyone. I just want to give an important message here by this. The intent of learning anything and capabilities inside you can only be taken out by you. **Trust your struggle** This quote is a building block of any house of your dream. I am not landed into cricket but I am happy that I am providing a better life to my parents. Instagram connect - 🇵 🇺 🇳 🇰 🇸 🇹 🇦 🇦 (@helloamanraj) • Instagram photos and videos **ThankYou for reading**

I am not one of those inspirational people who had difficult experiences in life. I am not someone who started literally from the bottom and made it through the top. No, I am just an ordinary person with ordinary struggles but big dreams. I am still young and I still have a lot to do in my life. Small childhood achievements But I am proud of many things that I achieved when I was younger. I used to be an honor student. I love how I see my parents’ proud faces whenever I would come to the stage during recognition ceremonies where medals would be put around my neck. I used to be a campus writer during high school. I am not the best one but I guess some people saw something in me and they told me that I had the potential. So, I was often sent to writing contests and I would often bring medals and awards. I even made it through the Regional School Press Conference. Our paper even made it through the Nationals. For a teenage girl, that was already a huge achievement. But of course, my high school career would eventually have come to an end. Three years later, they don’t even matter. I got a full scholarship in a small private institution for college and finished Bachelor of Science in Information Technology. Since it was a tri-semestral school, the supposed to be four year degree was shortened to three years. I graduated in college at 19 years old.  I started working freelance to build a portfolio for myself and increase my chances of employment. I got my first office job at 20 years old, which happened just a month ago. This job brought me a taste of freedom. Although, I am not actually independent yet but I am halfway there. Those may be small compared to other's achievements but I am quite proud of them. I am allowed to feel that way, right? What am I really most proud of? I hate waking up in the morning because that means that I have to leave the fantasy world of dreams where everything goes my way and then I have to wake up back to the reality. I hate leaving my bed and leaving my comfort zone but I still do them. I have to go to work just like everyone else. Since I live in the Phillipines, one of our biggest problem is the lack of decent public transportations. The trains are currently being repaired and has only 7 trains working. It takes an hour or two to wait for the train and when they come, people are squeezed like a tuna fish inside just to get to work. I have to put on my game face playing the chasing the bus game. Same with the trains, people are squeezed inside like a can of tuna. Chances of being groped, your stuff being snatched away during that 15–30 minute ride on the way to work is incredibly high. In fact, I lost count of how many times someone has inappropriately touched me accidentally or not or how many little items in my bag were lost. One of my greatest fears used to be being around the crowd but I have no choice but to be around them every single day. It doesn't get any better and I can't afford using uber or taxi every single day because they are incredibly expensive. Complaining won't do much. I just have to face it and get used to it.  Sometimes when work becomes too stressful to handle it makes me want to go to the bathroom for a few minutes then cry about it because I have to face this everyday. I have many insecurities, I have many doubts, I have many questions and in the back of my mind there’s always a voice saying you’re nothing, you’re worthless, you won’t reach anything in life. There are dark times where I could find myself believing them and I can’t get up from this misery that my own mind created. But I will eventually find a way. There is no room for quitting. I have so many dreams and I don't want them to remain a dream. Perhaps, this is my biggest achievement. Finding my motivation to reach my goal despite of how hard and stressful it is. I’ve also been chosen as one of the Quora Top Writer 2018. That’s gotta count too, right?

Disclaimer: I don’t mean to boast. I managed to win the very first race against a million other ‘would-have-been’ brothers/sisters, which is the reason am here today.I have never won a race after that.They called me a champion when it was marbles time(popularly known as Kanche or Goti).I had more than 15 1.5 litre bottles filled with these little shiny gems.Until 9, I had nothing to be proud of academically. But the day came when I was awarded the first prize in an Essay competition.Interestingly enough, I was the only participant from the primary section of the school, the others were all high school and middle school kids.I guess the other’s were just too bad. Or was I just too good?They year after, I achieved the above feat yet again. When I was on stage, our now principal, who used to be our class teacher the year before, refused to award me my prize, because she couldn’t believe that a brat as naughty as I am, could actually win a fucking essay competition. (She missed the prize ceremony the year before.) Thereafter, I was sent to a boarding school. There’s where I achieved a lot of things - The first day my took me to this school, there were 165 students there, of which 85 had cleared the written test. Of the 85, 84 had copied from my sheet, which the invigilator happily circulated in the class, right before me. Of the 84, less than 50 cleared a screening for an interview. Of the 50, only 1 cleared the interview. The one that tried hard to fuck it up.The first day of the academic year, I noticed they used a bell to signal everything. Breakfast? Ring the bell(twice). School’s over? Ring the bell (20 times) Reading time? Ring the bell(once). Your playing time’s over, get your ass back in the castle? Ring the bell(a hundred times), fucking hard. Within hours, I developed an enmity towards that bell. And as always, I had that tingling feeling of doing something rebellious with it. I wanted to fuck things up in this new place. After school, you’re usually allowed to play until called back. What did I do? I sneaked out of my classroom before the last period and sprinted near to the bell and rang it like it had never been rung before. I had my eyes on the classroom doors. The few seniors, who were discipline heads, came running out and spotted me, came running towards me while I was just laughing like an idiot(I still remember this scene like it happened yesterday), meaning to convey “the damage is done, big guy. Shut your run up already! hahaha” I was down on the floor, my senior held me there, my principal stood right before me, and I was lectured for over an hour. For what it was worth? It was a MIND BLOWING DEAL!I walked in to the playgroud, with a detention for the whole month, like a boss. The news spreaded fast and I was being congratulated by faces I didn’t even recognise. That was the beginning of my achievements in that school.I went on to become one of the toppers of that and the next four academic year.The seniors had grown fond of me, owing to my rebellious nature.Everywhere I went, there was an incharge for others, and then there was one other just for me.The detention classes: We are expected to stay up late until midnight and either learn new words, write lines that spelled the name of god, or just simply read a scripture and right a summary of what you read. Trust me, it only sounds easy. When you’re waking up at 4:30 every fucking day, you’re already half asleep all day. And then they make you stay awake. That’s some sick punishment right there. BUT. Like Fred and George came to the rescue of the Hogwarts students from Umbridge, I, the 12 year old brat, came to the rescue of all my friends in detention. Of course, I didn’t have any Weasleys' Wildfire Whiz-bangs like them, but what I did have were A HELL LOT of comics. I made a deal with everybody, that they’d do all the labor work they ask us to do in CBSE, in return, I’d provide them my comics, which they happily read and wrote the stories in their own words in a book. BINGO!I’d call that deal an achievement. I managed to run this scandal until 8th grade, I think that’s pretty cool. 8th grade:I was somehow made one of the monitor of the dormitory. Why the hell would I argue?I stood in the elections for the grade leader and won.(Grades 8–12, all have 4 grade leaders each, of which one becomes the chief. In total, you have 20 grade leaders, of which one becomes the Captain of the school, which is usually only from class 11th or 12th)Among the grade leaders, I won again. Fair game, public voting.I became the chief.First meeting I ever attended with the captain, I opened my mouth. Somehow, the 8th grade leaders are only expected to shut up and listen. But I had had enough with our library. That place had nothing but a stack of newspapers and a lot of religious books.After the meeting, I went to my captain and gave him a few marvel comics I had. That’s all it took. He got the funding from the principal and stacked the library up with Marvel, DC, Archie, Tinkle, Chacha Chaudary and others. A 10th grade leader asked me a favor and I obliged. He told me we needed books too. That’s when the super cool Captain brought in everything from Harry Potter to The Alchemist in to the Library.The librarian didn’t like me much after that because as a part of his job, he was supposed to arrange these newly arrived books in to different sections which he didn’t seem to enjoy. He resigned. He was mid 20s guy with a degree in Arts. What the fuck were you doing being a Librarian? Clearly, you don’t like books anyway.And then arrived an awesome librarian. Smart, Knowledgeable and right for the job. Achievement indeed!I managed to get a place in the school’s Basketball team.Point Forward, if anyone’s wondering. Fun-fact: I was the shortest player to ever play for the team: 4′5We managed to win a tournament that year. Yay! Shit feels like yesterday… Am I crying? of course NOT!Our team won the state level rounds for a national level IT competition.The school has a scheme, wherein if your academic progress has been good enough and had met the target given to you, you’re then taken to a trip to some place in India. Me and 12 others, from 1200 people in our school, were gifted a 4 night stay in Bangalore. We went to Wonderla!!!, it’s a water park.You know the slide where you need to be a certain height to ride it?Well the guy in charge of that slide denied my existence. But I said fuck it, this is mah lyf. I stopped midway. The ride came to a halt because of me. Lifeguards were all out. They had to save me. I was struck between a ride at some 60 feet above the ground.For a few minutes, I had the attention of every person in the 82 acre land. That’s an achievement!Am not prod of it. I did a stupid thing, don’t do this. Please follow the rules at public places, they’re there for our own safety.I hosted the annual day function and my parents, for the first time ever, couldn’t make it to see what I am capable of. And then they ask me how come they never get to see any of the things people say am good at.I wrote and directed a play for the annual day function.I don’t remember who was the chief guest, but the play got a standing ovation from every breathing soul in the crowd.But no one bothered to ask who wrote or directed the play. Pity!Writing is what am most proud of.And then the achievements are repetitive. We won two more Basketball tournaments in the following two years.I wrote another play in 9th grade for the annua day(I hosted it along with a friend. I hosted a couple of more events too that year). That one got a standing ovation too.In 10th grade, we were not allowed to do a lot of stuff. But we managed to do yet another play on the annual day (They missed me, I didn’t host it).
