I was very much hoping that people would love it and was expecting a standing ovation…. until a friend of mine playing a son in the play, who was supposed to cry, gave a chuckle halfway through crying, and the whole audience caught the sight and burst out laughing and the intensity was immediately lost.This was my last play in the school. I had to get it right. This scene was just the start, there was still some good 20 minutes of the play left. If the actors could manage it, and if the audience picks up the story, then it’s a win. And it happened, a standing ovation. Still, nobody ever asked who wrote/directed it.But I was still happy, very HAPPY.And then I happily gave my boards without learning shit. Came back to Mumbai! Haven’t achieved much after that, except - Discovering QUORA. Learning everyday through it.Meeting and talking to people who are actually the big guns of the real world.Thank you, QUORA. Thanks for the A2A, Annu! For people who don’t know her, she’s an amazing writer and one of the most underrated one at that. She mostly writes about Harry Potter, the book series and the movie franchise. And trust me, she’s one good observer. So, if you have a question from the HP series, she’s the one you ask. fin!

My baby sister is 5 years younger to me and currently pursuing MBBS from China. She studies 27 hours a day (her words) and will be a kickass surgeon one day. Mummy, Papaji and myself are all eagerly waiting for that beautiful day. Five years back when she discovered that medicine is her true calling, she knew she only wanted to do MBBS. She couldn't get a government college seat and we weren't affluent enough to pay the hefty donations all the private institutions were demanding. She took a drop, and prepared even more rigorously. Even though her efforts were top notch, the stiff competition and heavily politicized system beat her. It was then we found this university in China where she would get in on merit and not on donation and the overall expenditure, although hefty for us, would be spanned out across 5 years and it would still be less than the big donation amount the private colleges were demanding to give a seat. She cleared the same and at the young age of 18, she took the bold step to move to China and has never looked back. It was a big cultural shock for her, and along with the highly demanding academics, she had to manage everything else (literally) on her own. My baby sister, who hadn't even deposited a cheque in the bank, managed everything beautifully. She learnt to read, write and speak their language, found a house on her own, managed her finances every month and cracked all the exams every semester. She made alot of mistakes along the way but learnt and emerged stronger everytime. My parents managed the funds for her in the initial years, they pooled in their savings, took education loans etc. Then sometime back I too started earning well and took over for my parents and started to contribute financially for her education and monthly expenses. It's been 2 years that I've been earning well. My fellow colleagues have saved enough to purchase a car, travel abroad, give down payment for a flat, buy gold etc, but I have minimal to zero savings, and I couldn't be more satisfied. My parents look at me with pride and my sister is giving it her all in that foreign land. My friend Talha told me these words which touched me - "You're an enabler Suvadra. You're enabling your sister to learn and achieve her dream. We are proud of you." I think seeing my baby sister grow into this wonderful human being and helping her on the path to become a doctor, is my biggest achievement. Every time she saves a life, I would know that I am a part of it. :) P.S: That's my sister in the picture. Please send some blessings and positive energy her way.

I have no hard-earned degree which would allow me to stand a in well-respected company of peers.  No certificates to hang upon my wall or letters-of-standing to follow my name. Yet I am educated and intelligent. I have yet to make a lasting contribution to either the arts or the sciences which would preserve my name and leave a legacy deemed worthy by the masses. Yet I like to believe that I have touched the lives of those my path has crossed and left some impression of merit behind, as many of them have left with me. I have no title beyond the familial save friend. I've never been knighted, though I have been called Sir on occasion, and my armor of will has been scuffed and tarnished by life. Yet I would defend those I love to my dying breath. I've made no blazed no trails into the unknown and the paths my feet have trod were all well-worn by those who went before me. Yet I have made wondrous discoveries for myself in the realms of literature, the cinema and music which has catapulted my own imagination light years away and left me with a love for words and a hunger for more. What I have accomplished might seem minimal to some but they were accomplishment nevertheless. Yet which of them might be the greatest and a source of pride? It's appropriate that this is the first question that I stumble upon this morning because my eldest daughter's graduation ceremony was last night. She is quite proud of herself, as she well should be, for she's already taken a job as a result of that education. Yet I am prouder still and so very happy for her.  Which leads me what I deem my greatest accomplishment - raising my three children as a single parent. In this day and age, I know there are many who can relate to this. We love our children and give them our all. We set our own dreams upon a shelf, somewhere in the back of our minds, to gather dust; in turn, we help them discover their own and lift those dreams up, into the light, to be set free. And we whisper in their ears to chase them for all they're worth. They are all grown now, though the youngest is still in college. A tall, strong son and two lovely, intelligent daughters. I am not a prideful man yet I am proud of them.  Would you like to know a secret? Even were I to have riches untold or had climbed the highest mountain or swam the deepest ocean; were I to have composed a symphony or concerto to rival Beethoven himself or penned some masterpiece of literature that would be remembered and loved down through the ages...my answer would be the same. The role of parent is an unheralded one and that of single parent even moreso. It is not one, I believe, that any of us expect to gain praise for and, were we to, it would likely seem silly or even embarrass us. I certainly wish for none. We have the love of our children and the knowledge that we kept them safe and taught them all we could before releasing them out into the world. They know our sacrifices and we, in turn, know their dreams. And that is enough.

My biggest achievement was to learn writing a diary. It took me four years to learn that. When I started I didn't know how to write, what actually I should write and why I even want to write but with all these questions in my mind I continued writing. I tried many different approaches. The biggest problem used to be to remember everything to write at the end of the day. Writing helped me a lot in reforming myself and achieving a lot of things in life. In the process of learning to write, I learned few things beside writing like, I am not writing to show others, I am writing for myself so I need to be true to myself.Writing is not a pressure for me but it's a way to dump whatever going in mind into diary and sleep peacefully.While writing any incident I actually get to realize my mistakes.It actually helps me plan and monitor my day.When I write what I want in my life, it turns into reality. Words actually have power.What you say to yourself indicates what your future holds.Writing is a way to analyze the past and create future.And biggest of all, I learned to thank for everything I have in my life. I always write a thank you note at the end.

Turning a so-called setback into a strength. I was born with bilateral cleft lips, meaning that the part below my lips was non-existent when I was born. Fortunately, I underwent a surgery when I was 3 months old, whereby my lips were sewed up properly and I looks normal. This might seem trivial as compared to many other diseases and facial deformities that others have, but it was still something that made me look slightly different from others. My nose was flat, and I had two scars cruising down the bottom of nose to the top of my lips. It never bothered me that I looked different. Until that time when I was in Primary 3, and a boy called me a “gorilla nose”. I remembered being shocked and had no reaction at first, but when I realised what he said in its entirety, I was sad and frustrated. Fortunately, my parents supported me and taught me the power of ignorance. It took a while, but I gradually learnt to ignore the bully and focus on the more important things in life. And interestingly, I started growing an interest in medicine and human anatomy, even at the age of 9. It was then that I decided that I was going to be a plastic surgeon when I grew up, to operate on children like me. It was the decision to turn my cleft lips into a strength that I would say is the greatest accomplishment I had in my life so far. It changed me. From a poor little nobody, characterised by her ugly scars, into one who actively used her cleft lips, in her self-introduction when meeting new people, in a speech about how appearances do not matter and as a form of motivation towards her dream career. I have held onto this dream to become a plastic surgeon since I was 9 years old, and 9 years on, at 18, I am still working towards it. Even when I do get into medical school and finally become a plastic surgeon, my journey would not have ended yet. I will make use of this greatest accomplishment in my life, of changing my perception of my cleft lips, to change the perception of other young children towards their own facial deformities too. Because, appearances do not matter. What matters is your perception of it.

I think that just growing up in such a privileged life fulfills what I want to achieve in life. And that is to find happiness. Even though I may not be the world’s most famous person or the richest person in the world, just being with my family makes me happy and fortunate. I often ponder about what life is about, and it seems like I can answer that question now. To me, happiness is when your life fulfills your needs. Not wants, but needs. In other words, happiness comes when you feel satisfied and fulfilled. Happiness is a feeling of contentment, that life is just as it should be. Since happiness is when your life fulfills your needs, the next logical question is, “What are my needs?”Many have offered to answer this simple yet confusing and complex question. However, I feel that the answer to this question is-family and your loved ones. Although some may think that family is not the most important, I have a reason for my statement. First of all, family provides love, support and comfort in your life. During the most challenging moments in ones’ life, anyone can lend a shoulder for you to cry on, but when a family member looks at you and comforts you, it is probably what you want to have at that moment in life. Overall, I think that my greatest achievement would have to be that I came into this world, not knowing what life is about. But now, I know, and I will cherish the fact that my parents did not coincidently give birth to me for no reason, but they want me to live a meaningful life. As the saying goes, “families are like branches on a tree, we grow in different directions, yet our roots remain as one.”

Living life itself is my greatest achievement in life. I was born and brought up in a middle class family with a younger sister.Being a elder one I was supposed to have lots of responsibilities since childhood. I was given a good education from a local private convent till 5th. Then I cleared an entrance exam for my further studies to join a boarding school (NAVODAYA) which is a dream for many students at the age of 10.Even clearing the entrance exam is considered to be the biggest achievement of a child.Parents use to send their children to coaching center with the proxy attendance in schools to train for the exams.I had cleared that exam without any coaching 😍(You can imagine the scenario of pride). While I continued my studies at boarding school I stayed away from home and never had any idea of the problems of my parents. When I was in 10th I had a ovarian cyst due to which I had lost my blood and was hospitalized for months together and could not attend classes.Some people even say I'm a lucky girl who got rebirth.Still I was successful in clearing my 10th board with distinction. After I got my strength I had another shocking news that My Father had a kidney failure and is been living with a single kidney since birth. When I was in 12th I lost my father and was supposed to take care of the family but never wanted to stop studies and stay back at home. Being from a middle class Indian family where responsibilities are more valued than education I was forced to agree to get married. I argued,quarreled and left home for sometime to convince my family to let me study.They had their own restrictions and gave me 3yrs time to do whatever I want. I'm pursuing my degree with my own amount and also looking at family expenses without any support. It's so easy to live single, but it's really difficult for a single girl to live without any support and with responsibilities I really consider every moment that I live is my achievement.  Well it's me 😊 Beyond all the circumstances, I never stopped being happy. Every moment You live is a chance to change what has happened then. God's plans are bigger than our past. So keep smiling always. Image Source :my gallery By:Bhoomika Basavaraj 😊

IT IS IMPORTANT NOT TO BE A NEGATIVE CHARACTER. MAKE SURE YOUR OUT PUT IS LIKELI TO BE A NEUTRAL OR  POSITIVE ALL THE TIME. THAT IT SELF SHALL BE GREAT SERVICE TO HUMANITY. GOD BLESS YOU

Biggest achievement huh ? Cool. Opens achievement section of the brain. Nothing found. Searches again. Prrf. Nothing. What now dude?! Closes achievement section. Suffers in silence. Cries in the corner. I don't know the meaning of achievement. Shit load of money, fame, lots of parties, superhot chicks, thousands of social media followers, ultracool cars, a private jet, and a villa in the coast of Hawaii. If this is what achievement means, man I'm screwed. I've got nothing. Damn. My whole life was a lie. Gets his senses back. Opens life section.Nice. That being said, I've achieved some simple things in life to smile about. Ok this is pure bragging. Go on. Read at your own risk. I've managed to make exactly 4.5 friends on whom I can bank upon at any point of my life. They'll be there for sure. Worth more than a billion dollar villa.I was a known face in college. Been a serial topper and hey, it's all about prize money and the attention. Nerd mode? Hell no. Last bench, novels, Quizzing, stageshows, and everything else which had the word “fun” attached to it. No, my notes weren't famous at all.I'm a polyglot. Yes, I consider this a bloody achievement. Comon talk to me ;)Managed to come out alive after a trek from a friggin forest in the western ghats. No deal big? Let's add, rain, darkness, snakes, elephants, leeches, broken butt and minus humans. How about that ?Conquering my fear of public speaking. Long back during school days it was a nightmare. Now it's just pure bliss.Conquering my fear of the unknown. 5 days at Airforce selection board and I came back a new human. One of the best days of my twenties.Transition from an introvert to an extrovert. Don't ask me how, but whatever happened, happened like magic. I don't know. I love this.From a tiny-whiny weak kid to a fit and healthy dude. This one felt epic. To all those losers who picked a fight with me at school, come here, I gotta talk now.Opening up with people without the fear of being judged. You guessed it right, I'm talking about dates, crushes and midnight tea talks.Learning and mastering the art of not giving a shit. I don't know whether redbull gives you wings, but this surely does. Flying mode activated.Quitting the job which sucked the peace out of me. 3 jobs in 1.5 years. Hell, yea.Conquering my fear of drowning. 2 months of training and I swim like a shark now. Water water everywhere.Learning one of the best things in life, cooking. Thanks mom. Come home, I'll make you a feast that you'll never forget.Hunting down each and every desire in my yearly bucket list. MorganFreeman mode.Talking about career, I've been lucky enough to land in a decent paying job at a PSU which takes care of my bread and butter for now.Last one, I've got a platform to quench my thirst for writing. Turning into a decent known face within 5 months on Quora, this is friggin awesome. Loving every moment of it.I can brag all night , but I've got a vacation to plan. So yea, bubye for now. Grateful. Blessed. Peace. P.s - Wondering just what the hell “4.5 buddies” is? Really, 4 complete souls, hence one dude whom you're unsure about, but he's an excellent soul to hang around with.

Warning: These achievements may not be unique to myself, as there would be many fellow Indians out there who would relate with me on many scores. A clichè they may seem, but here they are - My top 5 achievements: 1. My Engineering degree 2. My first job 3. My MS degree 4. My marriage 5. My kids Long version of the answer ahead: 1. Engineering degree - I was the first among my generation of the family and the extended family (my Dad's siblings' families) to acquire an engineering degree. Of course, the fact that I'm the eldest among all of my siblings and cousins worked to my advantage. But that's not why it feels like an achievement. It used to feel like an achievement when my Dad would boast to his friends that his elder daughter is an engineer. 2. First job - I had always led a sheltered life at home. Not even a glimpse of the hostel life, as I stayed right at home during college. And then I landed my first job more than 1300 miles away from home. Initially I would cry my eyes out, missing my family for the first few weeks. It was really hard to be completely on my own. But once the home-sickness faded to the background, I managed just fine on my own. I even had a tooth removed, and managed all on my own (although again cried a lot once the adrenaline rush was over). So, yes, it felt like a huge achievement at the time. 3. MS Degree - The first degree ever that I earned and supported on my own (under BITS Pilani's work-collaboration program) while still working on my first job , without an iota of financial aid from my Dad. Felt so proud of myself on my convocation day. 4. My Marriage - I almost got married to a wrong guy - wrong for me, that is. When I started receiving calls after mid-night while I was sleeping after a long tiring day (and the next day was again a working day), with the excuse that it's his so-called right to call me whenever he pleases as my parents had chosen him as my life-partner (I hadn't even met him once), it irked me a lot but I tried to adjust, and kept quiet. But it was too much for me when he started planning too far ahead, on my behalf as well, and suggested that I'd have to leave my job to be a home-maker and spend time with his parents. I'm not suggesting that it's a bad thing to do - to be a home-maker and take care of the in-laws. But, somehow, I couldn't digest the fact that someone whom I had not even met once, and was not even engaged to, had the gall to do all this planning of my life, on his own, according to his whims, without even trying to know how I would feel about that. So, I put my foot down with my parents (Thank God for them being so understanding and undemanding) and got myself out of that would-be-disaster marriage. Today, I'm a full-time working mother of two kids, and have an awesome life-partner (again, chosen by my parents), and full support of my in-laws. 5. Kids - Do I need to explain this one? Motherhood would be the biggest achievement for any woman, I feel.

I am quite proud of what I achieved in my life given my age (23). I've been a top student from my first day in school till the last one.I ranked fifth on the whole country in high school, and hence earned 2 fully-funded scholarships to Kuwait university, which most expats have no hope of enrolling into. Not only that but one of these scholarships actually paid me to study in university, so I took up that one.By the age of 13 I knew the Quran (holy book of Islam) by heart. And even though I'm no longer a Muslim, the nights I spent memorizing hundreds of pages are still something I'm very proud of. I was tested on 200 pages fully in one competition. And we're not talking about regular memorizing where you can paraphrase what you remember, no we're talking about reciting lines exactly as they are written. I remember the times I broke down completely and cried that I can't do it because my mind will explode but I kept going regardless. And not only that I scored very high and got a sum of money no kid my age would dream of as a reward.I got my bachelor's degree in English Literature and Translation with a high GPA of 3.8 and was given an “honor" appreciation degree.Once I graduated, I immediately got a job that pays more than the average fresh graduate in Kuwait.I have enough savings to live for months without working, which I'd say is rare for someone my age.I translated projects on http://freelancer.com and translated a ten-page article that was published and sold for money. I was also offered to actually write for money (but the feild wasn't suitable for me, so we didn't go through with it).I ranked very high in a translation competition on “translators without borders” that I was invited to their elite group that translates sensitive topics. And I have actually finished several projects with them since then.I work at a legal firm as an assistant, and I'm trusted enough to translate the documents around the office that don't need an official stamp.My English improved drastically in a short amount of time. I even scored 7.5 in the IELTS test as proof of my proficiency in English.On the personal level: I was able to marry the person I love against my parents’ wish yet still managed to maintain a strong relationship with them, in fact even stronger than before.I managed to beat an eating disorder (albeit mild) and return to normal. And I'm currently still fighting my personality disorder with every weapon I have. The fact that I never submitted to any suicidal thoughts or given up is an accomplishment in my eyes.I worked as a teacher for 2 years while I was a student. And to my great happiness I had little girls come up to me and say that they very touched and feel positively influenced by my advice and guidance. And to me that means the world.I got an official certificate to teach Quran when I was 15 and have taught countless people since that time. And even though I'm not a Muslim, I have no issue teaching someone who feels that learning how to recite Quran properly will enhance their quality of life.Lastly, I managed to get comments like this: Be it when I taught, translated, wrote, or went to depth about my mental condition, I've always had one goal in mind. I live for it and will die for it. And that is influencing people's thinking and leaving a good mark in their minds. I believe that the best investment is the investment in a person's brain. And if I could get one person to know a mental condition better, or read a translated book and learn from it, or read my answers and learn something new, then I reached my goal and will keep going. I hope that got people to know me just a little better since people seemed to think my life revolves around my husband.

Helping the people I care about answer one or several of their three fundamental needs. Doing this has helped me answer mine. Three fundamental needs have been driving human behavior for thousands of years: control, connection and consistency. Without them, survival and reproduction are impossible. Evolution has ensured that those of our distant ancestors who answered those needs lived long enough to have and raise children. But evolution is slow. That’s why our ancestors’ three fundamental needs are still with us today. Directly or indirectly, they drive everything we think, say and do. Our needs for control, connection and consistency express themselves in infinite ways in a world that has become less physically threatening but more complex and mentally challenging. Understanding and satisfying those three needs, both in yourself and in others, is key to ‘surviving’ in a modern sense. This means navigating the opportunities and threats of today’s world, communicating and influencing effectively, and achieving what you want for yourself and your children. Here’s a closer look at those three fundamental needs: >>> OUR NEED TO FEEL IN CONTROL. This explains our attraction to things like knowledge, food, shelter, freedom, choice, power, possessions, contracts, insurance, mastery and safety. But it also explains our attraction to risk taking, fortune telling and novelty, all of which are opportunities to test or improve our control. On the other hand, losing control over our life or loss of any kind, whether real or potential, is something we avoid and act on. >>>> OUR NEED FOR CONNECTION There is very little, including reproduction, that we can achieve alone. Evolution has hardwired us to assume we can achieve much more by collaborating with others and being sociable (watch how newborn babies instinctively attract attention, for instance). As groups we can produce more food, build safer shelters and defend each other. Sex is one of the most obvious manifestations of our need to connect. It is evolution’s way of making reproduction (and therefore survival of the species) appealing. But we also need to feel emotionally connected to the world around us, to what we do in it, to what things mean, to who we are and to who we might become. That’s why stories, not facts and numbers, resonate so deeply with us. On the other hand, isolation or exclusion, whether real or potential, are forms of disconnection we instinctively fear and may go to extremes to avoid. >>> OUR NEED FOR CONSISTENCY. This need supports the first two. How do we spot threats to our control and connections? How do we spot opportunities to test and improve them? By constantly checking our surroundings for breaks in the consistencies we know about. Consciously or not, we can’t refrain from filling gaps, spotting patterns, finding or inventing explanations, drawing conclusions, identifying truths and learning. The world might seem to be in a turmoil of change, but most of life is consistent. We know from observation and learning that the same causes have the same effects and that reality in its millions of tiny details—including our own thoughts, actions and identity—is mostly consistent with our expectations and remains so from one timeframe to the next. This means, crucially, that anything that we know to be consistent can be safely ignored in most cases. This in turn frees up our mind to pay attention to inconsistencies, which signal either threats to our control and connections or opportunities to improve them.

Every goal which we are able to accomplish is an achievement regardless of anything . However , when we are able to do something new and achieve success at the same time , the feeling is more rewarding . I have achieved something that I never hoped of achieving . I am a student . After clearing my class 10 exam , I started to grow interest towards film making … slowly I even started involving myself in some small projects . It was going on quite well . However , I was not very serious about it . In November last year , inspired by our PMs words against food wastage , i decided to make a documentary on it . We had no prior experience except in some minor projects . I gathered a team , comprising of my friends at school and started planning on it . Initially it was tough . Trying to synchronize everything was difficult . The level of details of the entire shoot which had to be addressed was enough to make someone mad . We had limited equipment and our technical knowhow was also not that great . Still we decided to proceed . It felt great . The urge to do something new was enough to make us go forward . Then the shooting began . I was the director of the short film . The shooting spanned over a period of two weeks and the editing part took another one week . We finally came up with a 8 min long documentary . Everyone was happy with what they had done . This was an achievement in itself but little did we know then about what more was about to come . I came to know about a short film competition that was arranged in a school fest in our city . I thought that I should submit my project . I did what I had planned . I did not harbour any hope of winning anything there . On the day the results were scheduled to be declared , I was called by the judge I.e. the person who had judged my short film . I went to him . There I received the biggest surprise of my life till now . The judge who is in fact a renowned short film director gave me an offer to work with him in his upcoming project ( I have not yet thought about it seriously though ). And guess what , we won the first prize . Here is the link to my short film on food wastage :  And here is the prize received by me :  Here is the picture of us shooting a scene ( I am not in the picture )  Thus , this is what I have achieved . To be honest , I have developed a whole new respect for all the film directors out there . I have developed a passion towards this field and right now working on two different projects . I want to pursue it as my passion but not my profession . The taste of success is such that one will crave to indulge in it day in and day out …..

This happened around 6 years ago when I was studying in the 9th standard. One fine day, I was on my way to school. As the road to my school was blocked due to construction work, I had to take diversion and continue. I continued to cycle, in a completely new route, which I had never been through. The road was dreadfully deserted and covered with thick bushes on both sides of the road. I suddenly found some brownish thing at a random place. Closely looking, a gunny bag caught my attention which was inside one of those bushes. Despite fear, I went near the bag and opened the bag with confidence. OMG!! My heart skipped a beat on seeing the sight. There was a huge sum of money inside.  The poor me thought of buying lays chips with that. But was afraid to the core and something insisted me not to take even a rupee from the money. So, I thought of informing to the Police but was scared of Police. I somehow gained courage and went into the police station which was very close to my school and narrated the whole story to the police. First they laughed at me, but somehow agreed to come with me to that place. We reached the place and they were stunned by seeing the gunny bag full of money and they praised me. Higher police officials applauded me. They asked me if I wanted anything. I told them that my teacher punishes me if I ever go late to school and asked them to narrate the incident to my teacher so that she doesn't punish me. A policeman followed my bicycle and we reached the school. He narrated the whole thing to the teacher. She along with my classmates praised me immensely for my act. From that day, everyone in the school started respecting me. Next day, an article in the news paper was published about me. I also received an invitation from the district collector for a small meet. I met him and he praised me for my bravery and congratuled me. Later, I had a chance to meet the state Governor and I was said that I was about to receive a medal during the independence day celebrations. I was on cloud nine. On the D day, I reached the headquarters of my state ( Chennai) and the independence day celebrations started. My heart was jumping and pumping with joy. I was sitting in the middle row among few policemen, ministers etc. I was like a tiny flower in a sugercane field. The awards distribution function had started and I was waiting eagerly for my name to be called. My ears were adhered to the speaker. I was thinking of my friends who will be watching me on Television and I started feeling proud. I even had a plan to take a photo with governor and place it in the show case. !! Beeeeeeeeeeeppppp!! I heard a sound suddenly. Thought it was intereference in the mic. Again !!! Beeeeeeeeppppp!!! Aww… That sound was so disturbing. Suddenly I got a hit on my back. It was my mom waking me up to switch off the alarm. It was then I realised that I had some good time dreaming about achievements. Why should only real achievers have all the fun haan? We(budding achievers) can also have fun!!! Cheer up!!

I wouldn’t say this is my biggest achievement, but I think it’s worth sharing. In highschool i was an all-state quarterback for my football team. I broke just about every record, lead my team the farthest it had gone in 10 years, and not trying to brag, but I was doing pretty darn good. After all, I was the best quarterback in the state. I was all-state, 1st team all district, and 2nd team all conference selection. I broke just about all the career passing records, and just about all the season records. Football was everything to me. My dad previously played in the NFL for 15 years, and grew up loving the sport and playing my whole life, being around locker rooms and just loving every part about it. In my time in highschool, I was happy in the present, but I was just so excited to see what the future had in store for me. After the games and before the games highschool coaches would always go up to me telling me how good I was, taking their time to talk to me. I thought I had it going for me. The previous year I got a call from Mizzou, and so I knew that they had interest. Southeast Missouri State also had interest. I knew I was doing well. The numbers said so, coaches said so, and my accomplishments were unlike any other quarterback in the state. After my senior year I was expecting to get, at the least, 1 offer to play in college. You wouldn’t believe the lack of interest all colleges had for me after senior year was done with. Days go by, and I get no calls. And what hurt most was getting no offers. I’m waiting for my phone to ring from at least one coach to offer me any type of scholarship so I can go play for them and go to school. But get nothing. 2 of my high school buddies who were good athletes like I was got a great amount of scholarships to play. And I got none. I was shocked, discouraged, and a little bit scared. I was also resentful, and pissed off that no one took any recognition into what I had done and how hard I had worked. I asked myself over and over: what would I have had to do that I didn’t already do to get 1 single offer? The worst part was this is what I loved most and what I was best at at the time. I ended up getting a couple of walk-on offers, but nothing seemed real at this point, and still got no actual scholarship. To this day I can’t believe I did not get one single scholarship to play football and I will always know how wrong the college coaches were. I decided I wasn’t going to play. The head coach called me into his room, shocked and surprised that I wasn’t going to play at the next level. I told him I felt discouraged because no one offered me. He said it didn’t matter, I needed to go prove myself. He was right, but in my head I didn’t know how I would do this when nobody really gave me a fair shake in the first place. I was pissed off, resentful, and done with all of it. My whole goal was to make it to the NFL. And I knew I had little to no chance doing this with literally no college wanting me. After the senior season was over I quit. Who knows what I would have done in college? But I never had gotten a fair shake in the first place. If the colleges don’t want me, then they sure as hell did not deserve me.

Short Answer - The courage to fail..!!! Detailed Answer - I have never hesitated to try new things or take a difficult path. My understanding of life is to explore as much as possible. At some point in your life you will find it worth taking those risks or loses or victories. I love this quote by Steve jobs, “You can never connect the dots looking forward, you can only connect them looking backward”. I am 25 years now and I can confidently say that I have at least basic experience in different fields that most people wouldn’t even think of it as a career.I have worked in a startup where I had to develop a complete module (Frontend to Backend) as a fresher.I have worked in BPO.I have worked in MNC and enjoyed their benifits and a software engineer’s life (How our parents would imagine).I have riased 3 startups and learned a lot. (Selling saplings online, Catering, Idly/Dosa batter selling).I have tutored school students as well as corporate people.I have done freelancing work.I read a lot and continue to do it.EDIT: I started a YouTube channel UnboxStartups. Exploring the content creator side of me ;-) Do subscribe if you liked my videos. I am 27 now and added 2 more years of IT experience in my career. I am feeling more mature in terms of making decisions and handling the situations. I know a lot of people who will laugh at this list as they have a huge list of achievements. But I don’t consider these as my significant achievement but my courage to take risks and not afraid of failing is my significant achievement.

Well - whatever it was, it was shortlived! I performed my drag ballerina act, Madame Galina, for troops in Iraq. For three reasons: Money, publicity and lust. I was a risk act, to say the least - the squaddies expected to see straight stand up, football managers or all singing/all dancing glamour models. Not a sixteen stone drag ballerina getting their colonel onstage and checking for waggle in his under-feathers. I was last on the bill - and not because I was ‘headlining’, either. It was because the other comedians refused to go on after me and mop up ‘when the carnage has been and gone.’ Before the first show in the wilds of Iraq, I was so terrified I’d get canned off, I had a serious urge to climb the wire and flee into the desert. The audience was all Royal Marines and 2Para. The toughest of tough crowds. The act before me lost his thread and said to give him a minute. Immediately and in perfect synch, the Royal Marines chanted ‘…59, 58, 57…’ The act said, ‘Yes, we’ve heard you Marines do everything together. Makes you too tired to be of any use in warfare, but at least when you get captured you’re au fait with gay rape…’ Which, you can imagine, was the end of him. I was up, prematurely, so went onstage on still wearing my regulation body armour over my tutu. Faces all turned to me reading WTF? I made a Brigadier, sitting centre front, help with my body armour. A frazzled, a push me, pull you with the Velcro fastenings, getting his rank wrong with each comment. Major, Akela, Arch-deaconess, etc. Ending in a pratt fall with the Brigadier pinned beneath betutu’d me. The squaddies bellowed. And they continued with me - sounding at times like a laughter track. Crowning achievement. But then we came to the volunteers from the audience part of my act. Where I’d been advised to target the officers. Which I duly did. Meanwhile, the Royal Marines pushed onstage the notorious huge and morose Commando, Stacks. Six feet two; baby of face, blue of eye, rocky of outcrop. Stacks previously had told me not to get him onstage to join in with my set. Though he had it thus: ‘Your tiddle-iddle-thud in your frock of many doilies.’ Adding, ‘You are to leave me unmolested.’ I was doing swan’s wings, staring up at him, he was at ease, looking his most baleful. I looked up at him. He looked down at me. I was clearly at a loss and atmosphere was leaking from the venue. So… I cupped his genitals, saying, ‘We’re in a dry camp, but here’s some rising damp.’ He hoisted me over his shoulder and ran with me out of the venue. He was about to stuff me in the hull of a tank when one of his fellow Commandos pointed out the journalist standing by with a camera. Stacks was disciplined for assaulting a civilian (me!) and made to clean the windows of HQ with a cotton bud. He asked for a second cotton bud and came to find me… I’d like to say that with my one cotton bud leaving those HQ windows completely clean and smear-free was a crowning achievement. But I’d be lying.

For many it’s some exam or award or interview or competition. For me it’s quite different. 9th standard. Annual Day Function of our school. Like every annual day it was nothing different. Started with awards function for academics and extra curricular activities. All awards were done for the day. Except for the one- Ideal Student Award. It is always in the last. I had submitted my name with whatever necessary documents. Few others had also submitted their names. It’s ritual that chief guest announces and felicitates the student for this award. Chief guest came. Opened up the envelope. Announced the name. But for whatever reasons nobody could listen the name except for him and those who were on stage. Till now you must have guessed who the boy is. Well, that is quite obvious. Yes that is me. But that’s is not the achievement I am talking about. I have already said it’s not something award or competition or something similar. My achievement is what happened after that. As I said only those who were on stage had heard what was the name, our principal, who was on the other side of the stage heard it and she couldn’t control herself after the chief guest’s failed attempts to announce the name. She ran fast from the other side of the stage and grabbed the mic. And announced, “And the Ideal Student Award goes to Anand Vyavahare. I would like his parents to come up on stage.”  What is achievement in that, you ask? Well it was not me getting the best award of our school. It was the way our principal had announced my name. She looked happy. I could clearly see the satisfaction on her face. I had my mom and my sister accompanied me on stage. There were all guests, senior teachers, me, my mom, and my sister. But guess what? Who were the happiest?- It was my teachers. I could clearly see it in their eyes, they were proud of me. As if I had achieved a biggest feat in my life. As if I had lived up to their expectations. As if I was their son… All of my teachers were happier than my mom and my sister. After the annual day, everyone was congratulating me for the award. But it was my teachers who would tell everyone how happy they were that I got the award, how good of a student I was and how I deserved it, even to my mom. And believe me I had never felt so happy, not even when I was receiving the award.  To me this is the best kind of achievement. Making your teachers proud. No matter what you do, your parents will always be proud of you. But it’s always your teachers who would be fair and never be biased. They would always tell you what is right for you no matter how hard it may sound. No matter who would stop supporting you, they will always be there to guide you. So it is only when you can make them proud of you, would be the greatest gift you can give to them. The biggest achievement you can ever get!!! I always feel it’s never about awards, gifts. It is about these small things. I don’t even remember how the trophy looked like, how much money I received, who were the guests, what I was wearing that day or how I looked. Not even how much my mom was happy. All I remember is how my teachers were happy and were proud of me and their love for me… Yes this was my biggest achievement. And I am proud of it.

My children. I know it would be a totally expected response to such a question. But, there are quite a few reasons for it. My wife. If I had not married my high school sweet-heart who has been my best friend, my confidant, my teacher, my biggest admirer and, of course, mother of my two children, I couldn’t have answered it this way.My father. He taught me so many valuable lessons - sure, at times, his little philosophical rants became a bit too much, but I use his quotes all the time - which over all these decades have become profound - including a few, off the wall quotes like “Son, if you don’t FOcus you f**k-us”!My friends. All of them who put up with me for years (decades) and listened, gave me feedback and at times smacked the heck out of me.Finally myself. Even in my fifties, I am not afraid of taking any risks - calculated risks of course. For example, I wouldn’t quit my job and move to the Himalayas in search of truth. But, if it developing a career in a different industry, adapting a different lifestyle for health, or working extra hard to learn and present in a different language, or learning to ski in my mid-thirties so I can motivate/encourage/accompany my kids on ski trips, I am always up for it. Leading by example that passion, commitment and dedication is the only way to ensure and celebrate success is in my DNA. As my father would say, “Anything worth doing is worth doing well!”And, finally, having compassion so that you don’t cross that thin line between confidence and arrogance, value of anything versus price and using things and loving people versus the other way around - is the only way to leave a legacy behind for their next generation.And, from what my children have seen so far (knock on wood) they are reflecting these qualities very well. I wish and pray to God that they continue to do so and live long to write a similar opinion.

This mignt not be the answer you might expect, but you'll surely find it interesting. It's out of my personal life experiences. Read till the end to know how it changed my life. Leaving shittiest people that you thought were your besties. If your thinking and character doesn't align with your so-believed-friends, leave them and move on. Find those who suits your mental health and encourages in doing stuff, not in going for another round of weed or hukka, but in things that'll make you better as a person. I promise you, you'll be amazed, rather shockrd i guess, to see a person that has same mind set as you. He may be a person you thought- “vo bacche log hai”. But that person has more to offer you than your bhai/friend who smokes & drinks thinking it's cool and makes him look swaggy. Remember, you always have the choice to leave people behind who are dragging you down. It's not a betrayal to friendship. It's not friendship at all if that's HOLDING YOU FROM GROWING INTO SOMETHING BIG & MEANINGFUL. We often find it tough in the beginning when you start to leave them. You'll be on your own when everyone has their GANG to show-off around your school/college. But TRUST ME! YOU'LL LEARN A LOT BY BEING ON THE OTHER SIDE. JUST BY WALKING ON YOUR OWN ON THE CAMPU, YOUR CONFIDENCE AND SELF BELIEF WILL BE ROCKETED. If you are able to do that, Congrats! you've changed and has the courage to grow into something big. Now it's time to make friends that help you become big. When you find them, Welcome to the 1% club. You are going to change the world into a better place. It's all from my personal experience. To say it, I've a set of friends in beginning of my Engineering. We were the gang with swag that no other had. I liked it pretty much, Gangs-Wars-Hype, Weed, Alcohol etc etc. But I'm seeing where the things were going. But I wasn't able to do anything about it. I'm just going with the flow. To make me realise or stop and teach me that “it's my life, I have to take decisions, I shouldn't go with the flow", GOD had to intervene. I'm met with a terrible accident- a head injury. Out on the bed for 3 months. It was my calling to realise that it's not what i want in my life. Eventually, after a lot of drama I'm finally free from all that shit. Now, I've successfully graduated with 7.5 CGPA. Got admits from Universities abroad and good girl, good life. Oh you want to know what happend to my so-called-swaggy friends? Most of them were suspended for some time. Then they were subject to detention as they weren't able to satisfy the required credits to pass on to next year. So some dropped out of college( & caught the routine line- I'm working on my startup). And rest were my juniors, cuss they had to complete the subjects to pass onto next year. See on how different side of the story I am? LEAVE those who aren't good for you. You'll see a drastic change in your life.

Running a 10 KM mini-marathon  This might not sound a big deal to some people, so first I’ll tell you something about me. You remember that guy from school who used to faint during morning assemblies, I’m that guy. I was lanky, underweight, and hence fainting during school assemblies was my thing. Fast forward to January 2020 and I decided to run a mini-marathon. I had 20 days to prepare for the marathon. The first day of practice and I was panting hard after running only 1.5 KM. I got better over these 20 days but I was never able to finish running 10 KM. And mind you I’m still thin so obviously nobody (including my closest friends) had thought that I’d be able to finish the marathon. 23rd February 2020 This was the day of the marathon (my 1st time ever). I woke up around 3.30 AM that day (had slept at 12.30 AM after a crazy game of Monopoly Deal). We had to catch a bus at 4.00 AM from my college campus to go to Kozhikode beach which was the starting point of the marathon. The marathon started at 6.30 AM, and I had a simple plan - run continuously for 30 minutes then for the next 20 minutes and then for 20 more minutes. But as I reached the 3.5 KM mark in 20 minutes I was dead, I was panting heavily and I sat down on the road and took a few sips of mineral water. After this, I decided to just walk for some distance and see what happens. I walked for 500 meters and then seeing the 4 KM mark I decided that well let's do this. Instead of focusing on the remaining 6 KM, I decided to take it 1 KM at a time. I shifted from walking to speed walking then jogging then again walking, speed walking followed by jogging. I continued doing this for some time, and then I got a major boost when I got a tetra pack of ORS liquid being served on the route by the organizers. ORS helped me gain my composure back then I started running again followed by speed walking and jogging and this continued. I took almost 53 minutes to reach 7.5 KM mark. The rest 2.5 KM I covered in mere 14 minutes. So in total, I completed the 10 KM marathon in 67 minutes and believe me from whatever little practice I had done although I had never run 10 KM I roughly had an idea that I would require at least 75 minutes to complete the marathon but well I would say that it was just amazing. Now that I look back at the marathon I imagine that what if I had given up at 3.5 KM. I'm glad that I did not give up. This marathon taught me a few things - First being that before the starting of the marathon there were many of my classmates (along with a friend of mine) who were making fun of me thinking that how could I run 10 KM but after completing the marathon (I finished the marathon earlier than all of these classmates of mine) I realized that I've reached a level of maturity in my life where external negative factors or comments hardly have any effect on what I want to achieve. I've become a more self-confident guy who knows how to get things done and done right too.Second learning for me was that one should never judge others because you never know what that person is capable of achieving. My friend made this mistake, he underestimated me but instead, I ended up finishing the marathon 8 minutes before him (and more than 100 people finished the marathon after me and before he could complete it).Third learning would be how to pace things in life the way I paced my marathon run.Fourth, this not actually learning but a realization kind of, so when these classmates of mine realized that I finished the marathon before them I did not say anything to them, I just gave them a thumbs up when they were appreciating me, so yes I've become mature enough to not let any sort of success go to my head and well that is good news.After crossing the finish line I let a sigh of relief, I unplugged my earphones (was listening to songs throughout the run), sat down and clicked a picture of the medal I received. This is an experience I'll never forget. Thank you for reading. Bye.

I was going to say writing some books but that came off as kind of shallow, getting a college degree, surviving to 46 yrs old (trust me I’m surprised about that one with my health ills) but are nice but really not that amazing. Then this question made me kind of depressed. What the hell have I achieved? I don’t have any children, I haven’t married anyone, I haven’t run for office,, won any medals, prizes, I’m not a celebrity, movie star, broken any world records. I am not a billionaire (nor millionaire). I haven’t scaled the Himalayas in search of the yeti, nor the American Northwest looking for Bigfoot. I don’t even have a sleazy calendar or website. Getting a first tattoo at 46 is funny, at best. I then realize my only worthy achievement. Staying alive. I should’ve been dead decades ago. Death has it in for me, and he wants me bad. Crazies trying to run me over, child molesters wanting to give me a ride, lightning bolts narrowly missing me, near fatal bicycle accidents, numerous instances of random shootings only feet away from me, flying discus narrowly missing me, weird disease leaving me unable to swallow even fluids, a few savage beatings. How did I survive? Luck, willpower, too dumb to die? O  h, that angel of death will get me eventually, no doubts but so far he’s had an issue with my zig zagging.

“The house I build last year”.“The clothes I wish to wear someday, I wear those.”“The watch I admire for is on my wrist.”“The food I wish to have someday, I often have them now.”“The job that was not even expected from where I have belonged, I work there.” I am 23 and working form the age of 19. I pursued my education with my job. Now I have the full responsibility of my family on me and I am helpless. Money is now just a number for me, I am not rich but I am satisfied with it. Every 1st of the month my account balance goes up and then decreases by the end of it. I usually don't care about it at all. I separate my investments and saving initially and then spend whatever and wherever I want. Can we call it something biggest achievement? For some of you, it may be nothing and for some, it may be. Well, it's for me its nothing. Yes, money, house, and a good lifestyle is too important and is something everyone is working their ass off. but for me, The biggest life achievement I have gained is “My Peace of Mind”. Fortunately, I have somewhere achieved it this year as a blessing, and no one can disturb it. I think I have achieved something that is really and really important for this human generation. Humans have been literally playing with their brains and made their life miserable. I don't even give a fuck whether I have something or not. I celebrate my existence and the only thing I know to keep this body alive is food. May be 3 meals a day and anyone can work for that. It's just a bullshit myth that you even have to earn and work hard for that. Here I am talking about a hypothetical extreme situation, I know we have to earn to have good food, and it's not easy. But you know we humans are the one who has made it hard for the others. We are just like every other creature on this earth. Everyone works and arrange for their meal. Yes, we are gifted with super intelligence and that makes us superior by which we have made human life most comfortable ever it could be. We can proudly say we are the most comfortable generation that has ever lived on this earth. But can we claim we are happy, calm, peaceful as well? I am glad to have this calm state of mind. Nothing is more important for me than my existence. I do not panic for my problems, either I look beyond it and think for the worst-case scenario. Does it take my life? if no, what are the practical solutions to it? Sometimes there could be many solutions and sometimes acceptance could be the only solution. Believe in your karma and welcome your life phases. Never give control of your happiness and state of mind. Just go with the flow — “Anuugacchatu Pravaha” - Nikhil

Managed to get handful of enemies! A wise person said, “If you don’t have an enemy, create one.” Because an enemy allows you to work on your weaknesses and come out more strong and determined. When a friend appreciates your quality, an enemy works on your flaw to criticize and make you feel defeated. But, when you recognize your flaws, it puts you on a track to improve yourself to stay safe and secure. In fact, another wise person said, “Having an enemy is the sign of success.” And, here are couple of reasons for which you should get an enemy Your popularity will riseWhen you’ve an enemy, he will foul-mouth about you. And, making you popular by creating controversies about you. Coming out of it successfully put you in positive lights.Worst enemy can become your best friendYou can convert your enemies into good friends. And, such friends used to be loyal to you. Because whatever they do, they put their everything in it.They keep you focusedWhen you know that someone is your enemy, you’ll be super alert and focused on his next moves or activities and accordingly make strategies to keep yourself safe. And, when you’re focused, you can achieve something 100%.They can show “What’s wrong with you?”An enemy can tell you all the bad things about you. And, when you know it, you can put efforts to work on it. So, without them, you can’t know what’s wrong with you?They can bring the best in youIf you’ve an enemy, you’ll give your best to shut him. And, while giving your best, you come out as the best version of yourself. So, if they are around you, you’ll show your best version to them. So, in different phases of my life, I managed to get them and I guess that’s the greatest achievement in my life.

That I’m still smiling :) I’ve been through a lot of very difficult situations. I wish I could elaborate but I’m not one for pouring my woes out on social media to get sympathy. Sympathy is something I hate. So I will not elaborate. But I was branded a failure at several points in my life. In the eyes of the world, I had failed in every role - a student, a professional, a daughter, a sister, a woman. People predicted that I’m on a spiral pathway hurtling towards doom. I refused to give up… hanging in there by a thread of hope that everything will be alright, refusing to let the pellets of insults being thrown at me to affect me. And it paid off. After a while, the insults stopped… after they realized that it wasn’t affecting me. I was left as an imminent failure. They probably expected me to let go of that thread I was holding on to any minute. But I held on. After the insults had stopped, I started to heal. Slowly but constantly. Not even once did I stop smiling right back at life and at the very people who left me in that state. There was just one mantra that kept on repeating in my head - EVERYTHING IS GOING TO BE ALRIGHT. And that is exactly what happened. Today, I am in a very happy place. I am loved and cherished and I have never been happier. I knew that being sad and showing the world that I’m sad will only attract more negativity. I had had enough of that. I made smiling through my woes a habit. I rarely tell anyone about whatever has happened to me on my journey. And the people who know have told me the same thing… that it’s a wonder I’m still smiling :) If survival isn’t something to be proud of, I don’t know what is.

On my way to medical school, I went to visit my college roommate who had secured a job at a newspaper through a friend of my family. She gave a dinner party for me to thank me and I was sitting next to the NBC affiliate’s news director. Evidently, he loved to fill his newsroom with good looking women and very few and only necessary men. His producer was going back to college and he wanted me to replace her. He asked me if I would be interested. I laughed. I told him the only time I’d been in a television studio was for Captain Kangaroo when I was just a little girl. Besides, I was going to medical school. He continued to pester me throughout the night and then started calling me the next day. I relented and agreed to send him my resume when I returned home. He asked if I would just take the opportunity to visit the station while I was still in town. I agreed, again. Our appointment was conveniently set up just in time to watch the news live from the control room. I was transported into a different world. I fell in love the minute the first segment started… With the news, not him. Like many men, the minute he have what he wanted, he did not want it as much anymore. It was very frustrating and I was giving up my life’s dream track for a $12,000 job in one of the nation smallest markets. (To put that in perspective for you… Television stations are rated by the population and area that they cover. Currently, there are 216 markets and the population has grown since 1986 when I took my job. Back when I got the job, my station was ranked 156th And I believe there were only 167 markets.) Market size did not bother me because I was there to learn about the career I had fallen in love with and wanted to pursue for the rest of my life. I came from a newspaper background. I used to enjoy going in during the summers and writing cut lines (The quotes under pictures) and the obituaries. (When they only let you write two things, you learn to enjoy both of them.) I asked t advice of the family friend who supplied my roommate with a job at his newest acquisition and he was excited and solidly behind me. Then I went to my father, who always thought I could do anything I wanted to do. He did not ask about medical school or anything else. He simply encouraged me to do it… if that’s what I wanted. He even offered to pay to move me there… Saying that would give me a strong foothold since it was a small market and the station probably didn’t have much money to put towards moving expenses for a new producer. I did it. Not only that, but I got the job. The old producer offered to stay for two weeks to train me, but after watching her do one show that quickly circled the drain , I think her and told her to go on to college. The administration was astounded as were the anchors, but I assured them that I could do the basics and if I learned her bad habits… They would become my own. I wanted a fresh start and I had done my homework. I was a fast learner and I would not let them down. I did not let them down and from the first day I walked in there to start my job I worked 24/7, was always at the station and forgot completely about any social life… basically became invaluable. It only took me 18 months to move to Texas’ premiere communications company… The one where everyone wanted to be working. I stayed with them for the rest of my career, moving to several of their stations. From day one… It took me 5 years to become the country’s youngest executive news producer in a large market in the United States. I think anyone can accomplish something like this. However, when you’re dealing with television markets… You have to be willing to move anywhere at anytime and get paid what they’re willing to pay you… Knowing that one day it will all pay off. Unfortunately, you will now more likely than not find newsrooms full of people who started there as interns and will spend their entire careers at the same station. I recommend that you move as often as possible, especially if you work behind the scenes or as a reporter. It now only brings fresh ideas to the market, but you will learn more and make more money. My message to producers out there… remain a producer, even when you are a great one. There was a national conversation about the fact that once a news producer became really good at his/her job… they would get promoted… taking them completely off line. There are too few good producers. Stay in your bull pen. You can live anywhere you want every 18 months to 2 years and keep winning awards. Not only that, you will never be taken off overtime like you will when you get bumped up to the executive branch! You will be invaluable and, hopefully, treated like the rare gem you are.

To know my biggest achievement, I would recommend you to read this first.  TW: rape and sexual abuse “His weight on my body woke me up. I was 8, and while other relatives were attending a wedding, he’d broken into the house I was sleeping in. When I opened my eyes, he was on top of me. He was raping me. I was absolutely still. My eyes were open, and I was completely numb. I didn’t make a sound. He was my 35-year-old uncle, a distant relative. He ran out after. When I tried to pee, I felt an immense amount of pain. I bled profusely; my hymen had torn. I managed to wash my vagina, hands and face and went back to bed. I lay there still, and couldn’t sleep the entire night. I couldn’t comprehend what had happened. I spoke to no one about it; I’d never been so scared. I never saw him after that, but the trauma didn’t end there. After school, I’d go to a neighbour’s house for lunch. Once, when his parents weren’t home, he called his friends over. They undressed me and masturbated on me. This went on for 4 months. One of them fingered me so hard that I bled. I was lost; I thought showering would make things better. So every time it happened, I’d shower, hoping to ‘clean’ their dirt off me. I was disgusted– clueless, but disgusted. I still told no one. On my 13th birthday, 2 cousins groped me. I screamed at that time, but they escaped. I kept quiet about it, thinking I’ll be blamed. For the next few years, I felt depressed and cried all the time. I couldn’t sleep at night; I’d have palpitations and nightmares. To cope, I started smoking and drinking. It felt like there was no end to the attacks because the groping went on till I was 17, from relatives and friends. But the drinking led to a fibroid in my breast, and that’s when my parents started controlling where I went. Sometimes, I’d pack my bags and stay with my friend. Being with her helped– but I couldn’t tell her either. A few months later, when I started working at an aviation company, my CEO tried fingering me when I refused to sleep with him. I pushed him hard against the wall and ran away. That was a turning point. I swore to never shed a tear for these animals again. I started writing down my thoughts, cooking and going on evening walks to cope. I’m 18 now, and I’m in therapy. My body has been used and manhandled. But I don’t want to let another guy getaway, with anything, with a single goddamn thing. And to the ones who got away because I was afraid, all I have to say is, FUCK YOU.” “My biggest achievement: This is not my story.” I couldn't hold my tears after reading this article featured in ‘Humans of Bombay'. For a second, I thought that being an Indian it is an achievement for me. I am lucky enough not being get raped, isn't it? But what about her? Is she okay? Definitely not.  And what about these[1] - Rape is the fourth most common crime against women in India. According to the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) 2018 annual report, 33,356 rape cases were reported across India in 2018. Out of these, 31,320 were committed by someone known to the victim (93.9% of the cases). 33356 rape cases in a year, it means 116 cases per hour. Can you imagine? If you are reading this, I request you to respect everyone irrespective of their caste, colour and gender. Footnotes[1] Rape in India - Wikipedia

By far raising my two children was the accomplishment of my life, and the greatest challenge. I had been raised in a very strict, black and white family with mental illness challenges growing up so having a good rule book to follow was not mine for the taking. In addition to being ill equipped to deal with children, I was granted two extraordinary ones to raise - an artist who definitely saw life in colors and kept things mixed up, and my scientist who from the start would challenge all of societies beliefs on what a child her age could do. I have had to relocate, advocate and fight for both of them to have the opportunities they needed to be the most successful in this life - and every sacrifice along the way was nothing but a stepping stone to making me the best person I could be. Now sitting looking back I know every decision is one I would make again, despite the fact that family, friends and others did not agree and many did not make the trip to the end with me. The fantastic humans that matter are now a college art teacher, and a Phd candidate marine biologist, so I think I will be able to sleep at night with my decisions not weighing me down one bit.

Dreams? I can say, the day I have understood the correct meaning of this five letter word, my life has been transformed into a fairy tale. It all started with one embarrassing experience but a fortunate one. I had terrible stage fright. Whenever I was asked to present something in front of a group or an entire class, it had always been a disastrous experience.  One experience changed my life. I was mocked down by a group of boys in my second year of engineering, when I was called in front and as always, I was shivering and mumbling.  I took that laughter to heart and trained myself in public speaking. Months passed, and I started enjoying myself being on stage. I won several public speaking competetions, one after another. It was third year of my college and I already had three trophies at my name, job offers to train people overcoming stage fright and much more. This was a dream come true. Out of this, came my dream - To become The Greatest motivational speaker. On the top of my bucket list was to organise a motivational event " Drmz Do Come True " before completing my engineering.   It was a huge success. This was a dream come true. After innumerable failures and rejections, heartbreakes and crashes, I've recently launched my book The Night I Woke Up -which is a success in just a week!  I literally cried when I touched it for the first time. This is dream come true. I have transformed myself and my life into a fairytale because I always believed that it is possible. All of my dreams are now coming true. I love every single minute of my life.

I honor others’ experience of “achievement.” It’s a meme, isn’t it? One FULL of passionate triggers, that is, INTENSE reactions, isn’t it? But how many of us have been granted PERMISSION to question the notion? Most of us seem to just assume that the meaning is OBVIOUS, right? “This is what YOU did,” or “this is what you FAILED to do!,” are words and ideas, full of emotion, that we all seem to be accosted with from the very moment words seem meaningful to us, as mere toddlers. But how many of us have asked the question, “does anyone ever do anything, as in: EVER?” Have YOU ever asked yourself that question without IMMEDIATELY assuming a position on either the question (as absurd, perhaps?), or on the answer (as, for example, “of course everyone is doing, and has done, SOMETHING!” Suffice it to say that there ARE those who believe that we have no ACTUAL agency. That, in truth, Life, or The Universe, or Nature, or God, or Something Else Entirely, is acting THOUGH us, and we, ourselves, as separate entities, do NOTHING. We are merely a vehicle, or instrument, of some Other “Force Of Nature,” or some such extraneous Power. Be that as it may, I will wrap this up with two statements. My personally most satisfying “achievement,” if you can call it that, is to FORGIVE ALL. I call it Radical Forgiveness, and it means that I forgive all “wrongs,” whether real or imaginary, that have ever happened, whether “done” by other humans throughout history, or by animals, since the beginning of time, or by the Universe Itself. I won’t elucidate further, unless asked to.I strongly suggest that others ask themselves the very profound and meaningful question, “is there really any such thing as an Achievement?” But I mean to truly spend time on the question. To really postpone jumping to ANY conclusions as to what this might or might not mean. But rather, to sit with it, patiently, to see just what thoughts, feelings, ideas, quotations, inner voices, have to say to you. Just surrender to letting the question just hang there, without resolution. Just meditate and contemplate the question for as long as you can. Some might take seconds, to do this. Others, minutes, hours, days, life times. But I’m insisting that the LONGER one take to truly honor this question, the deeper, wider, higher and most fully will be the satisfaction in Pure Awareness As To The True Nature Of What It Means To Be Alive.

The biggest achievement in my life is that I am still living! I managed to survive until today and I still have the mindset to make my life amazing and to live it to the fullest. That, on it’s own, is the biggest achievement in my eyes.  I have a couple dozen medals from sports tournaments in my cupboard, have academic achievement awards I didn’t even apply for, have been published on amazing sites, have millions of views, helped a crazy amount of people and have reached truly mind-boggling achievements with them. None of these these are achievements I am not proud of, and none of them are anything to scoff at either, but these achievements aren’t what matters most. There were so many days I could have just thrown in the towel. There were so many days where it all seemed so much, where it all seemed like it wasn’t worth it, and where it would have been so much easier to just settle for a lesser life. There were days where I wish I could have just despaired, given up, and even a few where I wanted to end it all. But I am still here! I did not give up. I did not surrender. I did not let go. To me, that is the greatest achievement ever. It’s hard to live your life to the fullest… in fact, it’s hard just living in the first place! Choosing to live your life, day after day, choosing to keep going, to fight your fears, and trying to make the best of your life is not easy and I respect everyone who does this! My greatest achievement is that I am still actively living my life. I am still trying! I am still grinding! I do not just exist. I AM ALIVE!

Being happy with my own company. Becoming independent and living on my own! I always felt that I had to be part of a couple in order to be complete. I have lived on my own for just over 15 years, and with the exception of perhaps the first Christmas, I have truly never felt alone. I may have gotten lonely on occasion, but I have never felt alone! That is huge for me. I was desperately lonely and solitary growing up. I thought marriage would fix this and it didn’t, though in my second marriage, I felt a part of a family, with siblings (my brother and sisters-in-law) that I had never known. It didn’t relieve my feeling of being alone. In the months before I started out on my 15 years of self-discovery, I had decided that I was lonely and alone, and if I felt like that in a relationship, I may as well end it. Then if I felt lonely and alone, I only had myself to blame. Those were the smartest words I have ever spoken to myself. I thought I had the world at my feet and it was awesome. I didn’t think life could get any better. Then, almost nine years ago, I adopted my dog! My life is now happy, fulfilling and complete!
