Until now, This beauty…  This two years have been tough. Really tough. Journey as an advertising professional wasn't easy. But the good part was that this realization came to me way before time. Professional courses like mass media, business management studies needs to be practised inorder to understand the nuances of this businesses. During my college period, when my friends used to hang out after lectures. I used to spend my hours working as an unpaid Intern. Did I enjoy it? No. Did I learn from it? Yes, tremendously. I did have my days of frustration wherein I used to sulk about not getting to enjoy life the way my friends were getting to. Nevertheless, when the reality hit us hard in 2013, I realized things weren't looking bad at all for me. In fact, I was among the only 3 students who got placed immediately after my graduation. I remember my classmates struggling to get a job for whole of next year and unwillingly had to settle for unpaid internships for a certain duration. I got an amazing mentor in my first job. Credits to him on making me the professional I'm today. I revived my concepts and put them to use in the next two years with my first company. Then came an offer from the big league - which was the current organization. The Job required me to shift my base since my client HO was in Bangalore. I was really apprehensive about taking it up. The only reason was that I'm really close to mum. For me, Home is wherever she is. But at the same time I didn't wanted to be selfish since she had her Full fledged career in Mumbai. But what finally made me say yes was the offer to service one of the fast growing industry - e-commerce and also the fact that I was keen on taking up a course which was only available in a institute in Bangalore. From there began my IPG Journey.. A month into the Job, I realized I was the only person along with business director working on the account. That very year, we saw this e-commerce company taking over the market at a road runner speed. I remember working on 7 to 8 briefs at a time. Almost all the days used to end by 1–2 ish at night. And the next day used to start by 9 ish. If you truly love your job, you start appreciating each minute of it. Complaints were out of picture. Personal relationships did take a toll as well with no contact with most of my friends. The few who cared enough stays close even as if today. But it seems, your body doesn't always agree with your mind. I fell sick. And that moment, stress caught me really bad. It took me days to recover. I had to shift back to mumbai to recover properly. But in this one year with this client, we did manage to execute really good campaigns among which was an innovation that helped us build a connect with tier 2 cities in India by enabling free Wi-Fi zones for the masses and also supporting the cause of digital India. It led me to win my first gold at one of my prestigious media awards in India. After moving back to mumbai, I got the opportunity of servicing an FMCG giant in Mumbai. It's been a year now with them. Two months back, I got my company a silver (the one in the pic) for an innovation which was a marriage between digital technology and Out of time media. The second time definitely gave me a big high. Let's see if I can be lucky the third time? Few days back, I was asked to answer a question - which went like - what should I do to make it big in the advertising industry? I absolutely had no answer for this. Because no industry comes with a set of defined rules. It's only hard work that can take you places. My journey will be nothing like yours. But the only advice that I can give from my experience is we all must be - a WIP (work in progress) till the end of our time. The day we exclaim- we know everything is the day when we stop learning. That should never be the case.

Representing IIT Bombay and INDIA at two International Engineering Competitions related to Unmanned Robotics in USA and WON both of them. Intelligent Ground Vehicle CompetitionWe won the 25th Intelligent Ground Vehicle Competition (IGVC) which was held at Oakland University in Michigan, USA. IGVC is the biggest unmanned ground vehicle competition in the world for university students. Our vehicle ‘SeDriCa’ participated in all three events and secured first place in the Autonomous Navigation Challenge and second place in the Design Challenge as well as in the Interchangeability Profiles Challenge. We were placed first (overall) in the pool of 29 participating teams from five different countries. We were a team of seven boys scored total 88 points out of 96 points, beating the first runner-up from Japan by a margin of 32 point  ASME Student Design CompetitionWe won the Student Design Competition - World Finals organised by ASME's International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition that was held at Tampa Convention Center in Tampa, Florida, USA on 5th November 2017. We had earlier won the Asia-Pacific leg of the competition en route to the finals. Our robot participated in all five events and secured 1st place in the Sprint, Lift & Hit events, 2nd place in the Throw event, 3rd place in the Climb event and were placed 1st overall in the pool of out of 8 best teams from all the 3 regions (Asia-Pacific, North America and South America).  There is an Indian friend from USF in Tampa, who supported us a lot in the transportation of the big robot from our room to competition site on time as well as to the airport. He also helped us in getting tools, food etc. We are very thankful to him. PS : Apart from winning, learning and experience from these competition was very great. We learnt to network with different professionals, convincing skill, solve problems & on-spot issues. Working in great team also help to build the task more simpler and feel like “Let’s do it together”.

I survived a bad relationship. More like, its aftermath. And I learnt from it, and still use those lessons today. The year was 2013, and the story has been told before. She and I. Good memories. Cold feet. She disappeared. I faltered.  Those few months were pretty awful, and I remember them all to well. I had made the mistake of pouring in my life into a relationship that didn't last long. The end of it saw me broken and damaged, and I felt like things would never be the same.  I felt dependent on someone to be able to function properly. That, is a very toxic feeling. And with time, and help from a few good friends, I got out of the bad space. The experience was rather destructive for me. But with time, I recovered. I made new rules for my life.  I had two choices -  Remain the victim of the circumstances for an unprecedented period of time. Or Bounce back. And I did just that. That experience, in turn, taught me many things that have helped me shape a better life for myself. Which is why, I call my act of swimming against the tide my greatest achievement. Because drowning was never an option. I learnt - Never put the control of your life in the hands of someone else. Never remain stuck in a space for too long. Never stagnate. You just have to keep swimming. Things change. For better, and for worse, and not in any particular order. So, keep your head up high, and persist.Every thing that happens to you in life is a milestone, a lesson. Learn, and move on to the next one. There are more of those to cover.Your family and your friends will be there for you. Don't worry if your relationships fail. These people still have your back. Value them, and keep them close.Thank you for the A2A, Anonymous. :)

I did not have an idea that someone can cry for me. My colleague Shahin was crying from the core of her heart. I don’t know how to console someone who is crying. Emran’s eyes were wet, and he was trying heart and soul to hide it. My world stopped for a while. I have been rejected from everywhere in my life. Sometimes it was from friends, society, employers and relatives. You know, it gave me a sense of inferiority for a while. But this was a completely new experience for me. Shahin and Emran sat in front of me and were checking the file. I was trying to ease the situation. I told “Emran, could you please bring me the updated file of the sponsored child list?” He searched the file and told, “Dada, Here it is.” It was 5.30 a.m. I almost finished my work. That was my last day in office. I said, “Ok, it’s a pleasure and wonderful experience to work with all of you. Other field associates were continuously calling over phone and upset about my resignation. I resigned from my post for grabbing another better opportunity in job sector. Our project was being funded by Italy. Total 9 people were working in this project including me. 7 field staffs had to report and inform all the field activities to me. They had to report to me and my boss— who is project manager of this project. I had to report to project Manager who is the head of this project. All of the field staffs were undergraduate students studying in colleges and universities. Their family’s financial condition were not up to the mark. That’s why they were doing hard jobs at their early age. I always tell one thing to them, “Whatever happens, don’t leave your studies. Education can change the life of people.” Sometimes our female staffs used to share during conversation, “ Shovan bhai, We have to marry within a short period of time. Then, Education does not have any value. If husband does not permit, we will not able to do job.” I replied, “Future is always uncertain. We don’t have any control over it. But you have control over what you can control. Complete your studies, apply for a better job, become self-dependent , then marry a person who can adjust with your life and respect your opinion.” Whatever the work load in office, I always grant a leave before their exam time. For that reason, my boss warned me several times to give favor to the staffs. I never considered them as a subordinates, rather I viewed them as colleagues. I tried to work as a team. As a result, I got tremendous team effort. I used to inspire them, supervise them not only as a boss, but also as a mentor. There was a ambiguous system in our project office in which all the field staffs had to pay for lunch. I found that weird as the salary of a field associate was very poor, yet their work load was high. So, I withdrew the system of paying for lunch and made it free all the field staffs. I implemented the system despite facing several problems from authority. There was a huge pressure and workload in our office. We had to work day and night. Sometimes I pressurized to them for maintaining deadline because I had lots of pressure from donors, project manager and management to maintain deadline. It's been few months since I resigned from that job. Yet, my colleagues call me, ask for advice, and invite me to attend different occasions. Besides, I helped lots of families in my life who were unable to pay school fees or education materials for their children. As a result I’ve received love, affection and blessings from those families. I don’t know why they love me so much. I am not entirely selfless as they think I am. Sometimes excess love make someone guilty whether he is eligible for it or not. I believe that getting love from the people is the biggest achievement in my life.

It was September 2010. I had 104° fever, platelets were down to 48,000, Doctor asked my parents to admit me as soon as possible. It was a severe case of dengue. I had my interview scheduled at 3 pm in Gurgaon office of S&P Global. I had cleared 4 tough rounds 15 days back. Even standing was difficult for me because of the severe body & back ache also Gurgaon was 35 kilometres away. Parents asked me to drop the interview and go to the hospital as life is much important than career. Not going was the best option but I was in extreme dilemma because I had a secret which my parents did not know! I desperately needed to be independent from my father's business because I belonged to a traditional Jain business family and the love of my life was Punjabi. I knew my parents would never accept her with open hands and would pressurize me to take a step back. It was so important because living without her was not an option, if I could imagine my life she couldn't be missing otherwise no life was a better option. I got out of bed with help of my brother who knew everything and supported me. I bathed and got ready by 1 pm and asked my parents to take me for the interview. They hesitatingly accepted my offer. While we drove to Gurgaon I felt asleep in the back seat of the car. We reached by 2.30 pm. Father and brother took me to the office on the 9th floor. They were not allowed inside so I went alone. The desperate need and love forced me to forget the misery and appear healthy. The only other person selected from my college, one of my friend was already there, we shook hands. She stared at me and asked why my hands were so hot? I said “You know I am hot” She nodded in irritation & said “you have fever right!” We both sat on the comfortable sofa and she started preparing for the interview. I couldn’t study so sat silently. It was 3 pm and we had to wait till 6.30 pm for the interview because the managers were busy. These were the toughest three and a half hours of my life. My parents were upset and kept visiting me asking me to go back. But I had the target in mind. Finally I was called inside for the interview. A panel of three managers were sitting there. I had low energy so the best option was not to get too excited and answer everything soberly. It was a 25 minutes interview and my back and head were aching continuously. The fever could not steal the confidence level and after a wait of 15 minutes I was told I have been selected for the final round with the director along with my friend. The partial and unexpected success helped me regain some lost energy. Now started the round with director. I had an idea that he would intentionally try to be rude and check my patience level. (some selected seniors told us) He asked me several tough questions (not from finance just general questions) I tried to answer whatever I could but till then I had no patience and energy left in me. He told me I appeared dull and uninterested! I said I stay calm like this only. At first I thought to tell him that what I was suffering from but then decided not to tell because sympathy can't make you a winner. In the end from what I could see he was a bit confused for me but finally shook hands with me and asked me to leave. When he touched my hands he just stared at me once and looked at my red eyes but didn't say anything. I was not 100% sure but from what I could see in his eyes being a senior Director and an experienced professional he decoded the actual situation. After 10 minutes of waiting I was asked to go back. I don't remember much after that and I was straight away taken to the hospital. I was released 2 days later when my platelet count increased. One day after being back at home I was resting and lying on my bed suddenly I recieved a call from the placement coordinator. Here is the conversation- Ma'am: Hi Anubhav! Me: Hi ma'am! Ma'am: Why are you not coming to college? Me: I have fever ma'am once I get well I will bring a medical certificate! Ma'am: Ok! take care! but why didn't your interview go well? I expected you to perform your best and by the way Juhi has been selected. Me: Ma'am I couldn't help I have severe dengue and couldn't perform well. Ma'am: But you could have told me I would have requested them to shift dates. Me: I thought it would not have been possible so at least I should give my chance to it. Ma'am: Anyway you have also been selected! Me: What? Ma'am: Yes! congratulations and I am proud of you! don’t forget to bring sweets when you come back! Me: What? (again) Ma’am: Yes you are selected! Me: Thank you ma'am! I had tear in my eyes because first of all I didn't expect to be selected and second a lot was on stake. I joined the company a year later, While I was on training I once met the same Director in the pantry, he called me and we had the following conversation- Director: You had high fever that day? Me: You still remember my interview sir! Director: Anyway you performed well! Me: Thank you sir! That's it!

Ah - the question originally said “greatest” and I’d been unable to answer it. “Biggest” is more manageable! It’s a tossup between being invited to NYC (I live in Australia) in 2002 to attend a concert at Carnegie Hall where a couple of my pieces for chorus and orchestra were being performed by Baha’is from around the globe …  Under a microscope you may just be able to see a grey-haired figure with a grey tie (in the colour alphabet, grey is for Graham among other names) standing at the far left at the front of the stage, about to take a composer’s bow. The CD’s no longer available, but in the booklet there’s a close-up of me proving I was actually there. If I didn’t have this CD and the program, I’d be doubting it ever happened. There’s been nowhere to go but down ever since. … and an opera I composed, The Abandonment, being chosen for a theatrical run of four performances in Sydney in 1991. At one performance, after it was reviewed, there were 13 people in the audience. Not bad, eh? Very auspicious number. Just as well it wasn’t being performed in the Sydney Opera House, though the premiere was booked out which makes me feel a lot better. My natural inclination toward absurdism puts this achievement into its true perspective - it may have been ‘big’ but it was also of zero significance (aside from the company that mounted it going bust), and I wouldn’t mention it if the question was asking what my “most successful” achievement is, because this big achievement was an equally big failure! But both were big achievements for a composer nobody’s heard of. None of the works has been performed since, so I don’t get to dine out on them - no royalty cheques come my way - but at least when I call myself a composer I know I am one. (Or was one?) Thanks for the A2A.

An elegant mind expresses honesty with regard to its endeavours and accomplishments. It does not view them as a source of pride that sets it apart from others. Conversely, it does not undermine them, but simply states what is. Which is my best achievement? I like this word…best. Doing my best. Living my best life. That makes me smile :) I believe that living my best life involves a series of bests. I have learned to celebrate each one to the best of my ability! As for the word “received”… do you mean as a reward for my efforts? My view of achievement is that it is something that I work towards and earn as a result of my efforts. Any accolades I may receive will be a result of my energetic investment, not the cause. Achievement is the result of focus and dedication to a goal. Nobody or nothing is going to bestow this upon me. I believe it is imperative to chart and set the course of my ship, and then follow through with enthusiasm. I have learned that what I receive will be of the same energetic signature as that which I extend. It is the Principle of Reciprocity at work. I offer as examples a couple of my most satisfying achievements to date… I have been singing since I was a teenager, but it was not until approx. 2012 that I decided to get serious about writing songs. Up until then I had been content to sing other people’s songs and write short stories and poetry. I realized that I truly enjoyed writing songs! As I got more into it, I realized that I had to learn a bit of music theory in order to write good songs, so I began learning to play guitar. I am a novice guitar player but can play enough to create the melodies that I communicate to the seasoned musicians with whom I play. That took dedicated, focused work on my part…and really, really sore fingers for many months…but the results have been two studio EP’s Blue Muse and Cain’s Regret. My songs make me, and others, smile :) Last year I decided to compile the process that I developed in order to heal from the deaths of many family and friends in the past decade - so I could let go of grief and live my best life…it became a book that I called Saving Your Own Life: Learning to Live Like You Are Dying. It was published in June 2016. This book becoming a reality is the result of decades of experience; years of dedicated study, research and contemplation; many months of hard work; and a significant investment of funds for which I also worked. Where my music or my writing takes me does not concern me. I simply keep putting the good vibes out there and going with the flow…being open to the good stuff… That makes me smile too :) I am happy, because, having set up the conditions, I am receiving my best life in every moment of it…and that, my friend, will always be my best Achievement. An elegant mind creates goals and objectives and quietly works towards achieving them. Until then it is content with what is.

I caught a thief. This is no academic achievement. It's an incident which happened with me while I was in Mumbai, India for my studies for 6 years. I have penned down the incidence and it gives me a sense of achievement. It was the day(31 may 2014, time 7 am, Sunday) I was going to nasik(my home town) by Pushpak express(8.20 am from CST)after a long period of time. With one bag and a purse, I boarded the train on harbor line and sat in ladies coach to head to my destination, i.e. CST. There were only 5 more women excluding me in that coach(for those of you who might not know, harbour line is not much crowded as compared to other lines and it was Sunday, so less crowd) The train passed a few stations. It was now standing at Mahim station(platform 5). I was sitting on the 3rd seat(not near window or door) doing some task on my mobile phone. After about 20 seconds, there came a hand which grabbed my phone with two fingers. I was shocked ! I thought some familiar person might have grabbed it. But when I turned to find out who it was, that man snatched the phone out off my hand and ran down the door onto the platform. I was still in a shock for 2secs when my conscious told me -I wanted the phone !! Without wasting a second, I jumped off the train which, by this time had come to motion..In a rush, i jumped off the wrong direction( scientifically, you should get down in a direction in which the train is heading). While I should have jumped in the direction in which train was moving, I did opposite and there! I felt flat on my back. “Ouchhhh !” Was the word that echoed on that platform. I looked around shockingly to see not a single person standing on the platform ! It was harbor line time 7.20 - 7.25am. That was the time I realised I have to run and catch him. I gathered up all my strength and ran behind him. I wanted to catch him ! Seeing me running behind him, the cheat started running on tracks and towards the western line. For few of those who don’t know, there is a reiling between the harbour and the western line on Mahim station. As accustomed and used to stealing and running, the smart ass started running between the gaps of the reiling towards western line platform. I was still on harbor line. Helplessly, as I ran on the platform, I started shouting at the top of my voice for help. I shouted " pakdo pakdo chor !! Phone leke Bhaaga " !! (Thief, thief please catch him, he stole my phone!) Fortunately a few men standing on platform 1 heard my shouts and screams..they started running towards the bridge from platform 1. Realising that I couldn't run on the tracks, I also started running towards bridge from harbor platform. The thief by now, had reached the 3rd platform and was running now towards the bridge(unaware that I was also heading towards the bridge). Within a few seconds, he was trapped between me and the few men who ran to help me. Those men caught hold of him now! (*A sigh of relief*) I grabbed him by his collar and asked for my phone. He, very unwillingly handed over the same to me. Now was my turn. I started beating him up and down every part of his body using my hand and legs as well. My hands bleeding. My back hurting. My blood running down my shirt. But I had to do this. Then it striked me that my luggage is gone with the train ! My money, my belongings !! Nonetheless, I was determined to hand him over to the police. So I took him on the nearest platform (1st platform). Unfortunately, I couldn't locate a police officer/office. So then, I took him to the TC office which was on 1st platform. I narrated my story and asked them to call for police. I also ordered them to call up next station and tell them to get my luggage off the train and keep it safe. They did so. Surprisingly, the feedback from the next station was that the ladies from my train had got off on the next station and were waiting for me to come by the next train! It took around 10 minutes for the police to finally show up and to tell me " ye harbor ka case hai. Waha k police hi help Karenge”(this was a harbour line case and western line police couldn't help). So now, I again dragged him up with the help of 2 men who had helped me to catch him, climbed the bridge and took him to the harbor police near platform 6. Ok so now, there was a constant thought hammering my mind that I have to catch my train for Nasik and I have to reach CST anyhow before the time slips off. My next train was 7.47 am from mahim. It was 7.42 am now. The police told me to complete some formalities and to give them my phone. I said “I don't have time to do all the formalities.” To which they told me,”there's nothing more we can do to help you”. So I decided, let me just beat him up more. I did so and when I heard the sound of next train coming up, I ran again to board it and I sat in the 1st ladies coach. On next station, with God's grace what I see is- the ladies who were sitting in my coach when I jumped off from the train were standing with my luggage !! (It was surprising because we all were strangers to each other!!) Mumbai.. unbelievable! So helpful people. I took the bags from them(still standing at the door of the same train). At 8.18 am, my train reached CST station. My train for Nasik was at 8.20am. I had to run again to catch it !! For few seconds I just ran madly from 1 platform to another. And there It was ! On platform number 16- My train standing. I ran till my coach and only when I finally was on my reserved seat, I realised that my shirt was all wet by blood(backside) and my hands were still bleeding ! In the same condition I went till nasik and then my dad came to pick me up and I was straight taken to the casualty unit of my hospital(my dad is a doctor)!! Today, thinking of this incidence still gives me goosebumps. God, thanks for this experience !! It really gave me a sense of achievement. I could do it!

Let's talk about my last or latest greatest achievement(according to me ;-)) that is leaving all the social sites for more than about 6 months. Getting into details of it: I have uninstalled WhatsApp, Instagram and Facebook last December. It's been more than seven months now. I have not installed any of these but yes after finishing my important exams I have logged in Instagram in May in my siblings’ mobile because I promised myself I will not install any of these in my phone until I achieve all my desired goals of 2019. After May I used insta few times like once in a month in their phone only. It's a great achievement for me because I have never thought of it that I will feel so good after this simple step. It taught me how much crucial time we waste on seeing others’ lives day-to-day activities instead of working on ours. And I am still not saying it's a completely bad thing but still do it once you will feel how you are so focused on your journey, your goals, your aims, your people who care for you enough to keep calling you to keep that valuable friendship alive. You will become more productive because you are no more in auto- mode, you will start filling your life with creative and meaningful things because you will get involve so much in understanding yourself, your hobbies, your strengths, your weaknesses, your thinking patterns. There will be no involvement of any outside attractions. There will be no comparison, no inferiority and no “lena-dena” to many unknown people. I feel so grateful everyday that I have taken this step it helped me in finding newer version of myself and new hobbies like reading books and has also taken me close to my goals. Most probably, I will come back if there is any requirement or may be I use them by keeping limited fixed time but I would love to not have these apps in my phone. :)

Obtaining my M D was undoubtedly my greatest achievement in life. It was fraught with obstacles. My father refused to support my desire to become a physician, as he wanted me to become a nurse-midwife. Therefore I had to act as a companion to my unmarried aunt to ensure that I had a roof over my head and work for eight years as a long-distance operator in the Atlanta telephone office in order to save enough money for college. I was 26 when I started studying for my B S in Chemistry and Physics and the other students called me grandma. This did not stop me from having a good time but I kept my head down, as I had set my heart on studying medicine at Johns Hopkins University, to me the best medical school in the States, and I knew I would need the best grades to be accepted. I married during my junior year at the somewhat advanced age of 28 - at least it was for those days. But this did not stop me from graduating Magna cum Laude in 1980. So I got my place at Johns Hopkins but almost immediately messed things up by becoming pregnant in the second semester. I was urged to terminate the pregnancy or withdraw. I did neither. I discussed the situation with my husband and he agreed to start shift work so that he could look after the baby when I was at lectures. We shared all the chores and baby care 50/50. Without his help, I would never have gotten my M D. But despite the difficulties I encountered on my way, I finally obtained my degree in 1984 at the age of 34. Dr Julia

Success is different for each person as you will read within this thread when more people have answered for me to date I would say making people smile by doing something simple, like smiling at them for no reason, I take them away from all their problems and allow them to enjoy life for that split second, all worries and problems are gone, they have a smile on their face and are enjoying life for what it is at that very moment. Imagine for a second you are looking into a mirror right now would your shoulders are pushed back, your chest pushed out, your head held high, you are taking deep breaths, you stretch up and when you exhale you say yes very very loud, you have your eyes wide open and you have a smile across your face a big one not that smirk a really big smile the one that makes your mouth spread wide open and would make people stare at you because they would think what is wrong with you and you know your smile is showing them all just how alive you are and just how much you enjoy life right now, wait where is that smile I said smile, not smirk, there it is, yeah go ahead put your head up I see it I feel it there we go that's it SMILE. If you read this far you have no other choice right now you are smiling and if you are not then you know you have to know because life is just great and your smile is your way of showing life that you are it's master.  (If you are smiling and you feel a bit better now then you just did a second or two ago then I have just had the biggest success in life, here's to you and your success!) Yes I am smiling and so are you, enjoy life!

If you will ask this question to anyone, it may be possible that no one will say it perfectly, instead they may mention more than one. I too think that I won't be able to mention one single. Some of the achievements are - I have achieved faith of many unknown people. They met me and don't know why but they blindly believed me. Most of them are still friendly to me and even call me and treat me with respect. (I don't know if such a faith is really there or not, but I get to feel this). This might be because only I was there with them to help them in need.I have learned one thing in my so called life that is ‘to admit my fault’. This is something what many people take their whole life to learn. So I must count it as my achievement.Many times when I pass by any place I feel that women of the society deserves more freedom and I have influenced some(if not many) of the people to think upon this. This is also perhaps a achievement for me.If someone will say about materialistic achievement then I can say that I have managed to save a very small amount of money and some of the other useless type things. I also did achieve some awards during my academics and some for the sports.Moreover, an important one. One day I wrote an answer on Quora and it was viewed by some of the users and one of them(a girl) commented on it. After seeing the comment I felt nice (it was nothing more than a user can say). Let me show it to you - Thank You

My biggest achievement is getting out of bed everyday and going to school. I hate going to school. I’ve been accepted to a top university that my classmates couldn’t even dream of getting in. But I still get treated like shit. However, it wasn’t always like this. Before I began to be more public with my accomplishments, I was treated like everyone else. I had friends. I made the mistake of announcing my Stanford acceptance on social media and when I went back to school, everyone hated me. Don’t get me wrong, I’m not being bullied or teased. In fact, no one really talks about me, to my knowledge. It’s humiliating because I’m the first person to ever get into a school like that at this high school but I get treated like I’m less. I’ve always considered myself to be a very social person and I hate being alone but alas, this is my life now for the next few months before I leave for college. This may not be much but I’m very proud of myself to still gather enough courage to go to school despite feeling so alone and isolated everyday.

Raising our son to manhood. What could have been a disaster in our life, my last airline moving Dispatch from Los Angeles to Atlanta, became a godsend. My wife and I had, essentially, the same job at the same pay so I decided that we were not moving and I became a stay-at-home dad. Our son was never in day care and always came home to a parent. Even though I was tough on his friends, making sure that when the entered the house their shoelaces were tied and their pants were pulled up to their waists, they liked to hang out at our house. Shortly after high school our son joined the Colorado Army National Guard and enrolled at CSU as an engineering student. The Army paid for his degree, paid him monthly, and promoted him to Sergeant before his year-long deployment to the Middle East. After his deployment, he re-enlisted to go to Warrant Officer Candidate School. He graduated 5th in a class of 150 from WOCS and just graduated from CSU with two engineering degrees, Mechanical Engineering and Engineering Science. His three friends turned out well, too. One’s a Los Angeles County firefighter, one’s a Chef, and one is a High School History teacher.

I volunteered in an NGO in Mumbai in December 2016 for one month as a teacher. The students there had a pathetic life, with some of the kids’ fathers being drunkards and their houses being run by mothers. Some kids had parents who were divorced/widowed and couldn’t manage 2 meals in a day. Most of the parents were uneducated or had taken basic education in vernacular languages. In the last 10 days of my volunteering period, I was given the responsibility of teaching basic English(It was an English medium school) and by basic English I mean basic words like- The, He, She, Cat, Bat, Rat,etc to around 6–7 students from 4th and 5th grade in all. Now these words are known even to 1st graders, but those kids were so weak academically that they couldn’t manage to read these words properly. Now the challenge was those kids were hyper-active, and one slight distraction from anywhere and they would start dancing and laughing. I couldn’t scold them and I had to threaten that I would complain to their teachers. So for some time they would sit quietly and then again after sometime the same thing repeated. To teach them, I followed the method of saying the word and its spelling thrice, then asking each of them one by one in circle to repeat the same. After everyone had done that, I would ask them to write those words thrice in their notebooks; and at the end of the day, I would take a dictation of the words. I got and idea and as a punishment, I told the naughty boy(s) that they don’t need to repeat the word so I would skip their turn. So they used to make that innocent face of theirs and would feel guilty. Then in the end I made them repeat the words. It was going well; slowly and steadily they were learning new words, and were able to recall most of the words even after 3–4 days. After around 6 days, I made them read a paragraph from their English textbooks. As they read, their English teacher stood nearby and there was a wide smile of happiness and pride because most of them were able to read the sentences perfectly, though slowly. She was so happy! That day I realised- Having able to contribute something in the learning process of those under-privileged kids is my biggest achievement till date.

Hands down, finishing my first book. I never set out to be an author, but then I never aspired to be sued for $10,000,000 and defamed by the tabloids either! I have had a tendency throughout life to start multiple projects at once. I have countless unfinished and unreleased songs, music videos and random projects as a result. I believe I would be significantly more successful in life if I finished things before moving on to the next. Finishing a book was huge. First, I had to write four mediocre drafts before writing a good one. I went through crippling self doubt while publishing houses rejected me for two years. Imagine going through a traumatic event that was highly publicized only to find out no one wants your story. Eventually, my book found a home. Once I decided I would finish the book come hell or high water, the book got sold. Since mid December, I have been working on this book every single day in some capacity. I have missed tons of social events. I didn't really celebrate the holidays and I took a break from music. The last one is hurting my soul a bit. I wrote at the same bar stool from 2PM to 2AM seven days a week with a couple days off here and there. I realized every new project has a "honey moon" phase, which is why it can feel so hard to finish things once the initial high wears off. No media outlet, blog, Quora answer or interview can ever encompass the totality of what I experienced in 2014. The only thing that can do that is an entire book, in my own words. I'm hoping I can take this experience and apply this concept of finishing things to everything I do.

At age 70 my life has been filled with peaks and valleys… ups and downs… successes and failures. But I think that my biggest success was the one that came … almost in spite of itself…and despite my not even knowing what I was doing. I had retired after selling my printing company and was lucky to receive any payment at all for it as sales had been trending downward for over a decade… mainly because of the advent of the internet and the personal computer. We retired to Costa Rica and it was to be our “last big adventure”. But I became bored … even in the midst of one of the most beautiful countries in the world. So i started another business… with no experience, no startup funds, no connections and no technical background whatsoever. But I had nothing to lose! And I simply put one foot in front of the other and did what I thought was right. And within 18 months we had made more revenue than in the previous decade… we were featured in Newsweek Magazine, Investors’ Business Daily, Bankrate… and I was arguably one of the leading realtors and developers in the entire country of Costa Rica. I didnt think twice about it. Because it just happened. It was kind of like winning the lottery because it was all almost like it was preordained. And it took me ten years before I really did an autopsy on my business and what really happened. Then I got excited. Because, if you have ever heard the phrase “fake it “till you make it”… that was written for me. And even though we had phenomenal success and it really was… it seemed natural… and I also have to remember that we enjoyed the journey, every minute of it and I was never afraid of losing or failing. I cannot describe the feelings that were there during our time in Costa Rica except that they were exhilarating and almost empowering because I would simply do what I felt was right… and if something didnt work out… well, we didnt look back and went full steam ahead. It was my biggest success because at the time it didnt seem like it. We were even what I called “semi famous” and regarded as authorities in our marketplace. It was success because I was not afraid of failing and was not afraid to try. No, it does not always work out this way… but you will never know unless you try. Thanks for reading… my story is my reinvention.

When I first started working, I had absolutely no knowledge about programming or IT for that matter. I entered the field as a complete newbie. It was an entire shift of career in my life. Initially I used to find everything so difficult. I used to look at people typing incessantly on their systems and getting things done while I couldn't understand a word during my training period. I am a very slow learner. Things don't get into my head as easily as others. I need the thing to be told a lot of times to be able to understand it fully. And this was a completely new thing. I became depressed for a long time and had given up in my head. But quitting was not an option. But I knew I wouldn't be able to survive for too long. Until graduation I had never known what failure felt like, at least in academics. I had always been amongst the top students. But here I was the worst in the bottom most ones. It took me quite a while to understand that I have to be patient with myself. I cannot ridicule myself for not being good enough at something others had been doing for ages. And that I don't even have to compare myself with others. I have my own set of different analytical abilities which set me aside from mainstream. Reaching to this point of understanding myself required lots of sleepless nights crying, feeling inefficient, cursing myself, sad and what not. And here I am, been working for almost 2.5 years. I can proudly say that I have been surviving well. I wouldn't say I worked very hard and now have become a great programmer. I haven't. But I can say I have learnt and become competent enough to get my work done efficiently. At least today I am not what I was when I started working. I have built my set of abilities and credibility. I am not amongst the best programmers or analysts but I certainly have improved a lot. Learning to survive holds a lot of significance for me as it was a battle I have fought all alone. Sure, there were people I shared my problems with, but I could only get an assurance from them that I will be just fine. It was me alone who fought my own insecurities, incompetency, comparative mentality and negative mindset. And today, I can proudly say that I am doing just fine!

I had cleared IITJEE 2013 with an average kind of rank (3186) but I don’t consider that my biggest achievement. I had my biggest achievement and my biggest failure at the same time, 2 days back. On 8th January 2018, CAT 2017 results were declared. Here is how my biggest achievement and biggest failure look, aligned side by side.  I have scored 101.09/102 marks in Quant. I got 33/34 questions right. I believe my rank in Quant should be in Top 10 out of 2,31,000 students who appeared for the exam. This is my biggest achievement. I have scored 162.03/300 marks overall and an overall percentile of 98.19 in the same exam. I have failed to get calls from India’s top coveted B-Schools (IIM A, B, C, L). For me, this is my biggest failure. Ironically, I had given the least amount of time to quants and have scored maximum in it. I had devoted all the time to Verbal and DILR. I read newspapers for 1.5 - 2 hours every day, solved countless sectional tests of DILR and VARC but couldn’t perform well on the D-Day in these 2 sections. I had prepared for CAT 2017 religiously for exactly 4 months (August-November). It is usually said that an aspirant can prepare well for CAT in 3 - 4 months. In my opinion, the time required for you to prepare for any entrance examination depends (most importantly) on the knowledge with which you start – your origin on your preparation graph. Being an engineer, I guess, my origin for quant was way ahead (as much as that I didn’t even have to practice apart from mocks) in comparison to DILR and Verbal that I couldn’t get better even after rigorously dwelling myself in only these 2 sections for 4 months. I think my knowledge (at the start) was far behind those who are avid readers (who manage to ace the Verbal Section with 3-4 months of preparation). I should have started early. This is not the only reason though, I couldn’t sleep well on the exam day and I blanked out. But I am not going to let all my hard work and preparation go into waste. I am preparing for CAT 2018 now and I will prepare for 1 full year. Hopefully this time, I wouldn’t end up blaming myself.

My greatest achievement of life is ‘to know myself and be myself’. In my younger days, I used to be like the people who are considered to be successful. However, soon I realized that there is no fixed formulae of success and everyone succeed in their own way. You can find bosses who perform well by putting their subordinates under tremendous pressure and you can also find bosses, who succeed without even raising their voice. We admire Mahatma Gandhi who practiced nonviolence and we also admire Bhagat Singh who was a revolutionary. There is a place for everyone in this world. When we try to become someone, we are under constant state of tension. Please look the picture of two different springs in the figure below.  These springs are by design of different lengths. If you try to make the first spring to the size of later or vice-versa, both springs would be under the constant tension as they would be craving to come back to their natural size all the time. We are like these springs. We are comfortable being ourselves.If we live the life of any other person, we can’t be comfortable. I have tried to discover myself and then redefine success and joy for me. If I love reading and writing, I do it notwithstanding what other people think about it. I don’t force myself to imitate anyone or please anyone to win any favours from them. I don’t bother if others consider me successful or happy as far as I am able to be myself and do the things that I like to do.

I have moments in my life where I sit down and think about what I may or may not have actually achieved in my life. Sometimes I come out of those brainstorming sessions with a good feeling and sometimes I can barely go on when I am done. The times when I have a good feeling are when I realize that I am raising 6 beautiful and amazing children who will (God willing) go on to do amazing and beautiful things in the world. The times when I have a bad feeling are when I realize that humans cannot achieve anything in the world that lasts for very long and so trying to come up with something that qualifies as an achievement is really, really hard. However, ultimately the greatest thing I have achieved is the realization that I know nothing and am completely at the mercy of forces that are greater than I am. Why is this a great achievement? It is a great achievement because it results in absolute transparency with life happening all around me. I am no longer under the sway of my own delusion and can open my mind and heart to greater viewpoints than my own. Such openness has provided me with vastly more connected knowledge than I possess prior to this achievement. I have even come to understand how evolution, creation, and intervention work together to produce the reality we have right now. All in, humility has given me more than I have put into it and it certainly is not a weakness.

Ok so..i may not call it as biggest achivement but ya slightly on a bigger side (according to me) 1- i was one of those who was obsessed with both Instagram and Facebook .I would spend ample amount of my time wasting on these apps ,as soon as my obsession increased there declination of my mental health started. I would just scroll each and every feed. Took screenshots so that I could follow the same Started uploading a good number of insta status so that I could get reactions on my stories. There was a change in my behavior (I felt this) I would get irritated every now and then reason was simply my addiction to social media ( I tried implementing things which weren't of my type and this approach of mine landed me into irritation). No sooner I realised that somewhere I am hurting myself And that was it Now I have limited my use of social media (uninstalled Facebook and turned off notifications for Instagram ,and not to use social media until and unless it's necessary) It was just a mere achievement but yaa i am living at peace now 🙂..  Atleast i realised social media is nothing but a waste of time and it will make people depressed some day. Thank you for reading 😊 Edit 1- Thank you for showering so much love💓🤗

My greatest achievement in life was to actually getting serious about my health, showing immense interest, dedication to do it. I have never been that serious about my studies, carreer, dating, life etc. and so on. 2 great achievements: Stop Smoking.Lose 10 Kgs. weight.It is nothing new but the amount of time, dedication, control, focus these tasks need; they actually make you challenge yourself. 1st Challenge: Stop Smoking: I was not into smoking but still it is a habit you just can’t escape from. I got into smoking and smoked for 1 year more or less. After sometime I was smoking around 5+ cigarettes in a day, after every 10–20 mins I felt like I need some “fresh air”. I started to feel drowsy, smelt like ash and started hated that feeling. So near about 8 months, I started the fight to stop smoking: How did I do that? I quora’d all the stuff to help me stop smoking, side effects and good effects after smoking. There were many straight good answers on quora. I really thank to all quorans who answered too top smoking. I first started to make my mind stronger about why I should quit it. Then, I learned started saying NO whenever someone offered to me. I reduced my interaction with smokers. I reduced my daily intake. And started to cut it more and more. One day it’s just started as any other other day, I didn’t take a puff that day and after that it is more than 3 years. My previous short answer: What is it like to quit smoking? Fun Fact: You won’t believe guys, there is a phase, where you actually smoke in your dreams. After the dream, when I woke up in the morning and I smell like ash. Sounds crazy I know. You can google it. Dreams of Smoking Cigarettes While Quitting Smoking. If you find yourself dreaming about smoking cigarettes in the middle of a quit smoking campaign, don’t be alarmed. As this study suggests; it’s an entirely normal phenomenon and one to be expected during both chemical withdrawal and medium to long term recovery. 2nd: Losing Weight: Backstory: I was in standard 11th, 75 kgs and I was 5′8″, i checked my weight thought I am over weight, checked BMI it said 75 is ok as per my height. I promised to myself then that I will join the gym when i surpass 80 kgs. Year is 2016, indulged in my 2nd bad habit, Drinking; I weigh myself, 82 Kgs. So, I have to abide the promise I made to myself but it started due to another reason Here. I was kind of heartbroken at that time, within 6 months I had 2 heart breaking scenarios. So, I was actually searching on quora how to distract myself from the crap. And it was mentioned on quora to channel this energy into some positive activity and at multiple places I found that gym can be one of your place to chanel all that energy. So, I actually found a reason to join the gym connected it to my promise and channeled all the energy. Of course the path was not that easy, after work, reaching home and getting up from the bed. All parts of your body tells you not to go to the gym, you have to set aside all that and just dedicate yourself into the thing. How did I do that? First, mentally preparing myself why I have to do it which i explained above. Setting a target for my self. My target was to lose 10 kgs. It took me around 6 months to come into that range.  As you can see, the gym completely changed my life and I am still going for it. I am maintaining my weight as much as I can. While the above was ongoing, i had a friend with whom I discussed all the stuff and we helped each other in our rough patches. He forward me this video and it was so relatable.  You will surely love the video. All and all, sorry guys for writing too much. I hope, there are some more people inspired.

I know that I probably should say my kids…but making the kids was pretty easy (for me, anyhow), and even sort of fun. And raising them was challenging - but I firmly believe that parents have only a partial impact on how kids grow up; a lot is due to genetics. So I can’t really claim my kids as my greatest achievement. There are three things I am proud of and that I can take almost sole credit for - my doctorate and my professional certification. I’m proud of my Naval service as well - but a lot of people have spent time in the Navy. The doctorate was a lot of work - and I was also working full-time during my undergraduate, MS, and PhD work. So not only did I have to meet all the program requirements, take the classes, and do my dissertation research - but I had to do it all while I was working, married, and taking care of kids. So it was a little more challenging for me than for many of the other students. And I was able to publish 5 papers from my doctoral dissertation and another paper or two from my MS thesis. So I was proud of that as well. But I have to say that my professional certification process was even more difficult - the year I took the exam, fewer than 20% of those taking the exam passed it. Not only that, but I don’t have a degree in Health Physics (the science of radiation safety). So I had to do a LOT of self-study in order to be able to take and pass the exam. The other thing is that there are only about 1300 certified health physicists in the world - the success rate is lower than in doctoral programs. So one of those…but I’d hate to have to choose.

Probably, the biggest achievement I’ve made was starting my own band from scratch and utter confusion.  Hello, we’re Skarizon, and this is what we do! This wasn’t the first time I tried starting a band. Last year, I was part of a music club. My musical contribution came in the form of tabla solos, something that added to the cultural and musical diversity, and the overall sound of the club. There were two other members who also played Indian musical instruments - our club founder played the harmonium, and another member played the veena. For our school’s annual Art Stroll festival, the three of us played an Indian song with me doing a short solo at the end. Carried away by the success of that show, at the start of 10th grade, I tried starting an Indian classical music band and invited those two members. However, the club fell apart after the first meeting because, to them, it seemed like an extension of the other music club. The two people I asked to join also felt they didn’t have the time to join (note: I didn’t and still don’t have any hard feelings towards them, even though I was rather disappointed). During this same time, in jazz band, we started playing ska music. My jazz band teacher, Dr. Liddell joked about someone making a ska band and playing in all sorts of ska clubs. Even though he was joking, the idea still clicked in my head. I always wanted to start my own band, and ska music had a very happy, upbeat feel to it that would make it appealing to anyone. I started getting people interested in my band. At first, I was rather halfhearted with my efforts to get people interested; I didn’t feel too confident about the chances of getting our band successful. However, after 2019 came around, I firmly resolved to make this band not another failed idea of mine. I started asking more people more frequently. Before I knew it, I got two interested members. The first to join was our bassist Daniel, then our guitarist Rohan. I then spread the word of my band around school, and I quickly got more people. Our bari sax player Chayla was the next to join, followed by keyboardist Mark. I kept Dr. Liddell appraised of the details, and one day, after jazz band had ended, while talking to him, I was approached by our clarinet player Annabelle, who wanted to join as the pianist. Even though the piano spot was already taken by Mark, she still joined, and her skills at clarinet became quite useful for the horn section. Julia, our flute player, was “forced” into joining the band. Our last member of the band was Ron, the alto sax player. At first, he said he didn’t have time to commit to the band, but after a few months, I asked him again, and he readily joined. Now that I had enough people, I had to work on getting enough songs. Dr. Liddell sent me a long list of ska songs. In turn, I made my own list of songs that could sound good with the band (some of them were traditional ska, others were 90’s ska punk, and the rest were songs that could sound good in ska). Daniel started finding non-ska songs, including Rick Astley’s classic “Never Gonna Give You Up” and the popular rock song “Seven Nation Army”, and started arranging them in traditional ska. Only two months before the Art Stroll, we got our setlist ready. For another one of our songs, I chose the happiest ska song I’ve ever heard, “Latin Goes Ska” by the Skatalites. 5 of the people in my band, including myself, were also part of the high school jazz band, and we already played this song. Consequently, it was easy for us to teach the other two members that song. We played Daniel’s amazing arrangement of “Seven Nation Army”. Because we were given only 20 minutes for our show, we needed a third song. This one was “Spread Satin” by Roland Alphonso. Dr. Liddell conveniently had arrangements of this song, and he happily gave it to us. This song was the hardest one to master, but we managed to figure everything out during our last practice and were ready to play. Our show was amazing, far better than anything I ever expected. Sure, we performed in an outdoor area and had to deal with sheet music flying all over the place (not to mention somewhat poor sound quality), but the crowd was very appreciative and supportive. We were the first solely student-run band, and we played a very unique form of music that not many people had heard of. This is the video of our performance during the Art Stroll. It was our debut show, and we made a great first impression.  I’ve run 3 half marathons, reached black belt in Tae Kwon Do, had a successful first year in an FRC robotics team, made it to an awesome high school (I got into their IB program!), but none of those compare to the amazing feeling I got when my band Skarizon made it this far.

Quitting smoking? The birth of my daughter? Learning to swim a little at age 35? Graduating high school, then college, then graduate school, in that order? Living this long considering all the lucky times incidents that things could have turned out differently. I’ve shared a lot of stories on QUORA about near misses and times in my life I felt like I had to have had Guardian Angels watching over me. I actually still have quite a few more to share but for now I will mention this one. For instance, one time around 25 years ago while we were in Costa Rica on vacation we went with an local tour bus to see Arenal volcano up close. I knew nothing about how dangerous volcanos could be unless these were out and out erupting. We trusted outlet our guide locals. They seemed to know what they were doing. They grew up in the area and lived nearby afterall. We got closer to the volcano when it began to erupt ash. They stopped the bus and we all got out to see the ash. Before long the bus was covered in ash. I think it started raining? Like the volcano caused its own weather change? Suddenly it began spewing more than just ash, though that in itself was bad enough and the first warning to high tail it out of there. My husband remembers the bus driver and tour guide hurriedly getting everyone back on the bus and driving gas as can be out of there. I look back on this now and say, “Geez, what the heck were we all thinking” ?! We had no business not making sure before we even went that we were safe to go where we went and then at the first sign of ash we should have left immediately and not when things got that dangerous!” Until recently my husband had bags of ash from Arenal he kept as a souvenir. What I remember was that when we got back to La Fortuna we dragged our bed mattress out into the balcony on the second or third floor of the hotel where we could hang out and see Arenal in the distance with red lava flowing out. I thought that was so cool I did not want to miss a moment of it. I am not sorry I experienced this but that bus covered with ash is kind of a blur. I must’ve been frightened? Or I was clueless. Now I realize how lucky we were that something much worse hadn’t happened. I think we’d been to the Monteverdi Cloud Forest right before this and we were on a high from having seen a Quetzal bird and toucans and a sloth. Next we were headed to horse back ride and check out hot springs in Guanacaste. We were newly married only a year and this was more exotic and adventurous than I’d ever experienced (except for the month long Malaysia, Borneo, Singapore trip the year before). I trusted my husband to know what he was doing. I always thought he was smarter than I and more experienced at travel definitely. He’d backpack traveled throughout India, Nepal, Thailand and Indonesia and across the USA to Canada and along the west coast in a camper van before we ever met. I didn’t worry too much. I do usually go with gut instincts though. I don’t remember the volcano erupting ash incident in detail like my husband does. He says now that we were damn lucky. Departing from that volcano area in the tour bus covered in ash was a close call. It took me years to realize this so I never attributed surviving this to my usual Guardian Angels watching over or intervening. I happened to be reading about Costa Rica and volcanoes decades later. I was looking up Arenal and various popular spots to visit. That’s when I realized how risky that was and how worse things could have turned out. My husband wanted to go back and take our daughter there. I thought there were other “safer” places to visit instead. Arenal Volcano Costa Rica overview 40 Years of Eruption, The Arenal Volcano We were there in August 1993.

Raising six children who are trustworthy, kind, and lovable. None of my children have ever been arrested or become addicted to drugs or committed any significant crimes (or even insignificant ones). My eldest son spent 4 years in the US Air Force in Intelligence, signing up the day after 9/11. My middle and youngest sons are currently in the US Marine Corps Reserves, one as a stay-at-home dad of two and the other starting a career in financial services. My eldest daughter has been happily married to her high school sweetheart for almost seven years now and recently returned to college. My middle daughter is a sophomore in college and my youngest daughter is still at home as a freshman in high school. My girls are all musical - much more so than me: two play cello, two play piano, one guitar, one flute, one violin, one viola, one saxophone, and one has a particularly amazing singing voice, although they all carry notes pretty well - no bucket needed. Even my boys got in the act - one played trombone in his high school marching band and two played clarinet. All of my children tested as gifted or profoundly gifted in school (personally, I credit reading to them every night for many years - they all have a love of books that matches my own). But the achievement that I’m most proud of is that all six are trustworthy, kind, and lovable. It’s not about me. It’s about them.

I belong to that area of Jharkhand (India) where almost 99.9% can’t differentiate between IIT and ITI. To show my achievement, I will show you my 10-year challenge of what I had and what I have now. For this, I will be sharing some background details. so that you can just compare between me (10 years ago) and me (today). 10 years ago. Me:  My house(left one):  MY study table:  Road to my home:  My village:  Note: I used to take animals for feeding rather than going to school. One day, my stomach started paining badly. I took local treatment (12 km from my home), but the doctor (after trying several medicines) asked us to go to the city (case of emergency). My parents took me to the city for treatment (got appendicitis). After operation and recovery, I came back to the village. But what I saw during one week's stay in that city, was not going from my mind. I used to become happy whenever I remembered about the facilities they had. Curiously, I asked my father. How can I go there forever? He smiled at me and said: not forever, but if you score good marks in 10th, I can send you to study further (My happiness had no limit). Now, I had an aim that I have to go to that city and for this, I have to study very hard to get first division (criteria decided by father). But I had no one to guide. No one tells me what to do. I tried and tried and tried. And did whatever I could. Finally, after the 10th result, I got 70% (on state board). I was the topper in my school (at most went school 10 times a year). The principal came along with one teacher to congratulate me and then news spread that someone’s son has done very well and the headmaster came to congratulate (first time in my village). And from that time to now. Time has changed and it has changed me too. This is me now (in IIT Kharagpur).  B. Tech. (BIT Sindri- one of the famous government engineering college of all time in Jharkhand)(2013–2017). GATE- AIR-60′17. M. Tech.- IIT Kharagpur (2017–2019). Ph. D.- IIT Bombay (2019- till now) and will continue…… Part-time work- Now, I teach children of my village during vacations and till now I have taught four engineers (including me) in my village compared to none in the nearest 5 villages (10 years ago). It also helped one to achieve 3rd Rank in the state (district topper) in the 10th class. Now it depends on you whether you consider it as an achievement or not, but I do. Thank You. Edit 1: Thanks for the support. Keep supporting me, and keep motivating me. Edit 2: 1K+ followers now. All credit goes to this journey. This answer has changed my follower list from 4 to 1000 within a month. Follow me more for career-related doubts/ motivational stories.

I have been in active recovery for over six years now after using cocaine for more than 20+ years. I had a very traumatic childhood, gave a child up for adoption, 2 failed marriages, losing my children’s love and respect, a toxic family, battling depression, bipolar and countless suicide attempts since my teen years. One day, I woke up and completely realized that the drug life was no longer fun for me. I had attempted to get clean a few times, one period was almost two years. I picked up my life, moved 1000 miles away and asked God to help me. My relationships with most of my family are severed, but at least now I can see that the root of all issues wasn’t my drug addiction and mental illness. Those were just the reasons my family would use to ignore the deeper stuff. I miss my children every single day, but I’ve learned that in time, things will fix themselves. Crying and being depressed won’t bring my children back to me. I’m now free from the chains of my trauma, my addiction and my mental illness. I live in a great community and am very blessed to be a nanny and help others with their children. I live now knowing I’m doing my best with every single day and never take life for granted.

I’ll Bite. As I've stated in the past, I believe it is better to have a general sense of what you want to do in the long term and set short term goals that make you happy or provide a challenge or satisfaction. My life has always been a bit of a random walk. We are never in control of what happens in the next moment. So much of life is determined by randomness and luck. However no matter who you are or what challenges you face now, there is always hope. Achieving small short term goals feeds hope and can transform hope into expectation. Note that in the list that follows, I never set a goal of "happiness", "success", or "wealth". The only time I focused on money was when a friend and I were going out for lunch and we both mentioned we had very little saved for retirement. That comment spawned a partnership that earned us both a retirement fund. I have always pursued short term goals that made me happy or gave me a deep sense of satisfaction. Often the goals required developing skills over a long period of time. Sometimes it was fun, sometimes frustrating. Now and again I had significant setbacks as projects were cancelled or startup companies failed. As for love or relationships, I feel this does not lend itself to goal setting. How can we possibly know who we will meet tomorrow. To set a goal in love is to be unrealistic. Goals I've set and achieved: Before 20: 1. Get the highest grades in my year after screwing around for years and not caring. 2. Leave home as soon as possible. 3. Enroll at Antioch College, liberal work/study. 4.Get off campus housing 5.Using cookbooks, learn to cook meals from scratch. 6.Retire at 30 (a thought ,not a true goal and not realized). Before 30: 7. Achieve a degree in Physics 8.Study languages, Russian and German, and perhaps read texts in the original (didn't to that) 9.Meditate with a Tibetan Monk 10 Hike the Appalachian Trail through Smokey National Park in two days 11.
