It was a smooth piece of petrified wood, nearly physical to me. Palpable. Real. Flash to a vision of clouds reflected off the window onto the wall. The clouds flowed dreamily, in a purpley, blue sky, tinted slightly peachy pink. Opening my eyes, I found myself in my familiar bedroom. It was all a dream, but it was the clearest dream i’d ever had. It was the beginning of my premonitive deja vu. A few months later, i found the rock, the same day I saw the clouds in the exact way they were when I dreamt of them. After that day, I realized the deja vu was the way to point myself in the right direction. If i recognize it, it’s supposed to happen. I actually own some animals I once dreamed about. Most recently our gray kitten, who showed up in a moving dream 7 months before he existed. I’ve worked in places previously shown to me in dreams as well. The most notable was a purple dragon in a restaurant I spent almost three years in. Most recently, my dreams have been really telling. Big changes are afoot. I just need to trust that everything is as it needs to be, as it always was. Trust yourselves.

My achievements aren’t very astounding or even interesting — indeed, they’re rather bland and lukewarm in the overall scheme of things. I could only think of these (some aren’t even of my own merit):— (All images via Quora photo search)  Around the world as an urchin I grew up in 13 different countries around the world (as corporate urchin, not military brat). From that, I can safely generalise that I have a higher ability than most people in “cultural literacy” and being comfortable with ‘differences.’ In matters of language uptake, I’ve learnt to realise that the whole edifice of “language learning” is ultimately a game — one gets better in any language simply by playing along with the speech of the locals, and then the reading and writing will string along.  A life of learning … to unlearn everything I never went to school until the ripe old age of 12. Then I finished all my formal schooling by 17 — with pretty solid exam results. Then I went to uni for a three-year bachelor’s degree. In all, eight years from start to finish in the educational timeline. It brings up some interesting food for thought about exactly how much formal ‘education’ a person actually needs, doesn’t it? Lesson learnt about ‘school’:— Wow! It’s [f_cking] nothing! It’s just a game of playing “Pretending to Follow the Rules.” Or repurpose the school life as some kind of second-rate training camp for “workplace inoculation.” It’ll all be ancient history in a few years’ time — don’t sweat it.  ‘Work’ and ‘serf’ are four-letter words I became a book editor at a major London publishing firm at 17. It was entirely on the strength of my English-language abilities, not even on any formal paperwork. I’ve been doing that for 30+ years until I switched to printing. Uni graduates in Literature or similar didn’t get the job. No, I didn’t have to sleep with the publisher to land that job. I didn’t even have to sit next to her, in fact. However, my first-ever ‘real’ job (in the sense of ‘salaried’) was a labtech for a London teaching hospital. In those days, labtechs didn’t need anything more than a couple of O-levels and one A-level. It paid so insultingly badly that I didn’t have enough money to buy petrol to drive to work. I packed it in after 7 months. REAL BRAGGING RIGHTS  First home I bought my first home in London at age 19. Almost identical to the pic. Price paid £21,000. Registered a partnership firm to legally sidestep the requirement to be aged 21 or over for the conveyancing deed. When I resettled abroad, sold it for … well … let’s not talk about that … and I’ve been regretting it ever since — because I’d never imagined the price could hit £500,000 today!  The Isle of Man TT Motorcycle Race The TT (‘Tourist Trophy’) motorcycle race is by reputation the world’s toughest motorcycle competition. I entered the TT at the tender age of 19 or 20. I passed the entrance requirements, but failed in the first run. Such is life…  3M Panaflex sheeting I first introduced the 3M Panaflex signage and awning material to Hong Kong back in the 1980s. But I got not a cent from it. The sheeting material wasn’t taken enthusiastically by the local market, and some thought it was unsuitable for the local situation. So I dropped championing it. And then it suddenly took off and I couldn’t get a way back into the racket.  Concorde tickets I bought 12 Concorde tickets for London-New York at surrealistically dirt-cheap prices. I also bought a stash of other tickets on regular planes. The lowest priced was just £1. This was during the famous “air ticket war” in the 1980s, principally between British Airways and the now-defunct Laker Airways. The ladies suddenly saw me super cool, a super wantable jetsetter (short-lived, but still). I gifted some tickets to my friends, and so blimmin’ happy they were I have never seen in anyone before or since.  Matte coated magazine paper I’m the first person to print trade and fashion magazines on matte 60 gsm paper in Hong Kong in 1987 as “house default.” Up to then, such magazines were roundly printed in heavy 100–110 gsm glossy sized paper for full-colour printing. Today, most Hong Kong magazines are printed on matte 60–80 gsm.  One of the world’s earliest blogs I’ve been blogging for 20 years. My blog, The Naked Listener’s Weblog, was launched sometime in 1995–96 — you can tell from the word “weblog” that it’s oldskool enough. Won two awards for the crap I churn out on a regular, consistent and frequent basis over the years — until I injured my right shoulder in an industrial accident (and coming on to Quora!). Gone through four different hosting providers (ibm.net, GeoCities, Windows Live Spaces, and now WordPress). I think that’s quite enough bragging for one day, don’t you? Thanks for the A2A.

That’s a tricky question to answer. Especially as a parent and husband. Personal life- Overcoming the issues from my first marriage, which was very unhealthy, and marrying a wonderful woman. We often joke that we would both be more likely to be struck by lightening and attacked by a polar bear (here in Louisiana) on the same day then to get remarried when we did. We both had several younger kids. I had four kids of which three were under the age of seven. She had three kids with two of them below there teen years. We worked really hard to provide them all a stable environment full of opportunities. We didn’t do the flashy stuff, but we did provide them with a good start. We are still very involved in their lives and are extremely blessed. Professional life- That one is a wild ride. Being honorably discharged from the Marines and play football at the collegiate level were really good things. I didn’t finish college, which I still regret at times, but I did end up getting several higher level IT certifications. I used the work ethic instilled in me by my parents to work my way from menial jobs into a career in tech. That I parleyed into a, still continuing, thirteen plus year consulting business. My most significant accomplishment would have to be integrating wireless network handhelds into a maintenance group. The software we used (Computerized Maintenance Management System) called a CMMS did not support using the handheld interfaces wirelessly. I had conversations with the company and all of these add=ons to the systems were in there infancy. The more I researched and dug the more I realized I was quite alone in this endeavor. Everyone sees maintenance, delivery, and logistics personnel using wireless handhelds today, but in the early part of this century, not so much. I still remember standing, starkly alone, in the middle of our office building completing my first wireless sync of the handheld to the CMMS. I was jumping up and down. Pretty silly I know. The next day, after passing on my latest results, I was on a conference call with the software company, the owner, their leadership, entire software staff, and sales VP. They grilled me for a couple of hours and set up several follow up calls. I ended up doing more than fifty conference appearances about all of these things for several years. When at Tulane University we asked if we could present at the regional conference, for all the southeastern schools, and they laugh at us. A year later the head of the conference was calling us asking that we do a presentation. Pretty cool.

Birth day: Achieved to cry and breathe. 1 year old: Achieved to say a complete word 1 1/2 years old: Achieved to walk 3 years old: Achieved to not use diapers. 6 years old: Achieved to write and read 8 years old: Achieved to sum, divide, multiply and subtract numbers 10 years old: Achieved to finish elementary school 12 years old: Achieved to feel love for a girl…and kiss her. 14–15 years old: Achieved to finish middle school 17 year old: Achieved to identify what i would like to study in College and finish High School 17–22 years old : Achieved to kiss lots of girls, have sex, get drunk, have fun, go to parties, all while going to University. 22 years old : Achieved to get a degree in Engineering, and start a Masters. Also was able to fall madly in love, have my heart broken and learn from that experience, all while working on my first job. 23 years old: Achieved to fall madly in love again. 25 years old : Achieved to finish my Masters 28 years old: Achieved to learn from the experience of having my heart broken again. Achieved to move out of my country and work abroad. 28 1/2 years old: Achieved to continue kissing lots of girls, having sex, getting drunk, having fun and going to parties 29 years old: Achieved to give my heart a new opportunity and fall in love again 32 years old: Achieved to get married to the woman i have loved the most (as of that moment). 35 years old: Achieved to have a son. A beautiful, amazing and great boy. 36 years old: Achieved to learn from having my heart broken again and getting divorced from my wife. Achieved to have a 50% Custody of my son including 50% of the week with him. 37–41 years old: Achieved to continue kissing girls, having sex, having fun and going to parties, all without alcohol. All this while raising a beautiful son. I am 41 years old right now. I think my greatest achievement thus far have been : “To have the opportunity to live, with the ups and downs, all this while learning, getting smarter and loving more”. Things done at work, possessions, travels, money, are secondary and not important.

I won’t go for the non-physical things right now. We all know that love, friendship, and whatnots are also achievements but I don’t want to get boring or predictable. My greatest achievement is when I won this writing contest. I mean, yeah it’s nice and all but here’s the catch—it’s supposed to be in Filipino. I am not good in my iwn language since I grew up with my aunts and uncles teaching me English and then I went to a private school and then I have a lot of foreign and aboad relatives so I suck at Filipino. The writing contest was to talk about why Filipino is a great language and I did it with my own style. I wrote it as if I was casually talking to the reader. I used facts and also, real-life situations. It wasn’t the best but it was everything my heart and brain could say. I was contented and passed it and left the other students. The vicctory would’ve been sweeter if I was there but I was sick and tired that I stayed home and binged-watched The Flash. My sister came and announced the news and it was so awesome. I’m still 15 so there may be a lot of oppurtunities for best achievements in the future.

My best achievement till date is clearing my CSIR-NET exam and simultaneously caring for my twin daughters who were 3 years old and required my attention all the time. This might look too less for other people but to me it was the greatest balancing act. I did not have a mother-in-law to help and my mother would not willingly help me achieve my aspiration for she believed that my duty was only towards my twin daughters and was never towards myself. I had a father-in-law who believed that the daughter-in-laws duty was to simply keep feeding him every 2 hours with fresh food and beverages. He had purchased a maid servant without wages. The saddest part was he would cook and eat what he made for 10 days but if the daughter-in-law cooked, it had to be fresh every time. I did not have time to stand up and fight for all this. So I decided that I will instead do everything everyone wants and my sleep time I would use to study for the exam. My husband was not earning enough to support all of us so I managed a college teaching job, taking extra IIT/PMPD classes, cooking taking care of my daughters driving them to hospitals at night when they got sick, entertaining my father-in-laws brothers and friends and balancing my college job simultaneously. I would study from 10 pm to 2 pm and be up at 5 am to start the next days cooking. I would some how catch 5 hours of study in a day and continued like this for a year. I cleared the exam in my third attempt and was ecstatic. In a similar fashion I took 19 years to complete my PhD. To people reading my biodata it is just another exam and another degree. But the amount of trials and tribulations and the hard work and efforts I put in not just in my subject but in my family environment to get there was toooo much. It becomes extremely difficult to explain to interview boards as to why I took 19 years to complete PhD and why there is no continuous service etc. It is also unfair to have age limit of 35 years in all job opportunities. I am touching 45 years and as a married woman only now I am free to study or work as I want but when I see these age limit I really think it is unfair.

Writing my first poem. I was in Grade 9. My mind started wandering in the middle of class, and I pondered all sorts of inane things. The fan chopped overhead, barely providing any respite from the oppressive July heat. The teacher droned on about gravity, but my mind refused to obey fundamental physical rules and drifted out into the tepid garden through a window near the ceiling. I turned to the last page of my notebook and my hand grasped the pen, suddenly inspired. This is what I came up with: She was a blue rose, Floating high on a sea of green Yet concealed by a sea of red Alone, rueful, surrounded by the barrier Of her beauty. So real, but seemingly impossible. So lovely But still a mistake. And as the glorious summer sun Was replaced by winter’s pale disk The blue rose shone ever brighter While the sea of red receded. Alone, unloved, the blue rose waited A solitary speck on the ice While around her the snow melted And once again there were stirrings of life. Once again the sun glowed bright And the sea of red returned But this time the blue rose was too tired to fight So she withered and died. Upon my mother's insistence, I submitted this poem to an online magazine and received an editor's choice award. It was one of the proudest moments of my life.

Asked to Answer:My biggest achievements in my life so far are the below 1) Understanding the exact mix of emotions I feel at any given point of time  and analysing the root of that emotion 2) Realising that a human mind can achieve anything with the right attitude and right planning 3) Realising the power of thought and understanding it's impact on life. For eg:  analysing the current situation of mind and finding the primary root thought that lead me here. To make it more clear. Right now im working as a analyst in stock market. Now if i dig deeper and think what lead me here, this would talk me back to my childhood days when my dad used to talk about legends of Indian stock market and also how many of his friends lost money as  bed time stories. He used to tell me that it's risky and very rare to be successful in stock market Wait it doesn't stop here When I dig much deeper i realised the basic root THOUGHT of mine.That is " I DECIDED TO PROVE MY DAD THAT I CAN BE SUCCESSFUL IN STOCK MARKET " this made me work towards my goal. analysing deeper like about gave me lot of clarity of my mind and my actions and helped me to clear and filter my current thoughts that could impact my future. 4) Understanding the power of positive thinking 5) I can condition my brain according to the output I want. I can throw in any emotion and leverage it to create beliefs in my brain to drive me towards my goals. Understanding the above lead to many achievements and material benefits in my life with utmost happiness and mental peace. Have a happy life ahead :)

Graduating from one of the top public universities in the country with a difficult Biology major despite not being passionate about the subject, making it that much more difficult. When college started, I was pushed by overly-intrusive parents to be a doctor (aka the immigrant parent dream). I pleaded my case but you just cannot reason with some people, as I eventually found out. I was unhappy, miserable, and unfulfilled in what were supposed to be the best years of my life. At the time, I lacked the spine to stand up to overbearing parents who had no moral compass, if they wanted something done then they would use any manipulative trick to get it done. So there I was, miserable, and functioning on maybe 50% of my potential. The 50% number is very optimistic but regardless, I sat through classes like Biochemistry, Genetics, Organic Chemistry (1 and 2), and a rigorous pre-med curriculum made to weed you out. By the time I realized how bad of a situation I was in, I was too far along to switch majors. I could have dropped out, gave up, switched majors anyways to prolong college even more, or even have given up on life. Instead, I put my head down and powered through it. I graduated with a degree in a difficult track and from a top-tier institution. I also walked away with some key lessons. Do not let others determine your path in life, no matter how close you are to them.Life is pretty miserable when you are not doing something you are passionate about, so do things you are passionate about.When someone is doing anything unjust to your life, stand up to them, tell them it is not okay, even if it is your parents.

Identifying thoughts and separating myself from them. I've been a pessimist since childhood. I always used to think in the negative. Then a crisis happened when I failed to qualify for medical entrance exams and had to do engineering. My negative thoughts worsened. Also because of the fact that I broke up with my the then boyfriend. It wasn't until much later in life that I realized that I failed to get into medicine due to my neglect and not because I'm not capable of it. I did well in engineering and managed to get into an NIT ( a national institute of technology) for my masters. I was happy. A good student. Until the completion of my masters. I didn't want to do a PhD. I didn't know what to do. Negativity increased and I started falling prey to anxiety again. But thankfully things changed. Now I'm doing my PhD under a very good supervisor. Still I'm always anxious. I'm afraid I might not make it. However in the past year, I've begun dissociating negative thoughts. I've managed to witness a thought, and let it pass, without reacting to it. I read a lot of self help material and through that I've come to realize that our thoughts are not us. It was ridiculous at first, but now I can tell which thought is mine and which is noise. Sometimes I'm exasperated at having spent almost all my life enslaved to bad thoughts. Bad thoughts are not bad, so long as you identity them and gently put them aside. Looking forward to more Zen ! For this, I thank @Dushka Zapata, her books were a savior. I highly recommend reading them if you are searching for meaning. I also follow Kris Gage in medium. She writes amazing introspective stuff. I read one article of her everyday :)

I really can’t take any credit for anything I’ve done in my life. I never had the power to orchestrate events or achieve wordly status, which by the way, have never been on my list of what is important in life. My greatest achievement that earmarks who I am was my choice to receive Jesus Christ as my Lord and Savior, who died to save me from my sins. Since then, I am empowered by the Holy Spirit who operates in me and through me for God’s glory. I’ll tell you who I’m not . . . I’m not a college graduate or a scholar. I’m not certified, ordained, credentialed, licensed, accredited or approved by the state. I’m not the president of anything, not on the board of anything, nor am I the leader of anything. I’m not famous or well known. My name or picture isn’t on the cover of any magazine, and I don’t own any trophies or awards for a recognized accomplishment. But I know who I am . . . I am God’s beloved created in His image; forgiven, cleansed, set free and growing in grace. I’ve been purchased by His blood, and have hope alive in my heart. I am uniquely special to him, carved in the palm of his hand, and of significant worth. I’m not bragging, I just know these things about myself. I value my role as a woman, a wife, a mother, a friend, a sister, a neighbor, an employee, and a mentor; I bloom where I am planted. By the world’s standards I’m not highly appraised . . . I’ve been used, labeled, numbered, judged, categorized, controlled, manipulated, hired, fired, ridiculed, belittled, slandered, humiliated, shamed, threatened, criticized, and degraded. I’m not anybody’s boss nor do I climb the corporate ladder. I’ve never been nominated for anything, nor have I ever gotten voted into anything. I haven’t copyrighted anything, discovered, invented or patented anything. I never appeared on TV, nobody’s written a review on me, or asked for my autograph. I’ve never been called a hero, and I don’t own any medals of honor. I never reached the top ten of anything, and my community doesn’t even know I exist. By the world’s standards I haven’t accomplished much of anything. But I know who I am . . . An adopted child of God, alive in Christ, and empowered by the Holy Spirit with a peace in my heart that comes from a Heavenly Father who loves me unconditionally. Many who claim to know me cannot discern my worth; it is invisible to them. No one sees when I encourage or comfort someone slipping into despair. No one sees when I serve my family’s needs, minister to the hurting, talk with the hopeless, labor over an important project, reach out to the lost, or spend time in prayer. No one ever sees when I go to my Heavenly Father to ask forgiveness, sometimes full of shame and grief. No one ever witnesses my answered prayers, or my victory over sin. These things only happen in the secret places of my relationship with God in the sanctuary of my heart. No organized system or institution on this earth owns the final authority to dictate or decide who I am. My infinite worth in God’s eyes is immeasurable. Yes, I know who I am. . . I am God’s masterpiece, redeemed, set apart, sanctified, and justified. I am chosen and called, reconciled and redeemed. He pays attention to me when I call out in prayer: sometimes rejoicing, and sometimes full of anguish. He carries me through every circumstance I face. He is with me always and I shall never fear what mere man thinks of me. My hope is in Christ. I am complete in him. “Lord, all that we have accomplished, you have done for us.” Isaiah 26:12

Ah, my single greatest achievement to date is to have rediscovered the joy of learning. The greatest failure of my life is that this rediscovery had not happened at an earlier age. For though there is the inclination to learn, there is not enough vitality and time to be apportioned among kinds of knowledge. So I have to make do with what is to me of immediate relevance. That the enthusiasm of my youth is once again mine is cause for contentment. But forced am I to funnel this enthusiasm into specific disciplines. Now, my greatest achievement is not an achievement in itself, but a key to a whole multitude of them. It may seem like I have hinged my hopes on a mere feeling; yet the best reward is the reward you give yourself-- everything else is just embellishment. I am not sure of winning accolades or prizes or laurels. But I am sure of one thing: I will do my job well and derive satisfaction from it. How did I achieve this? It was not a mere awakening to something better, but the product of an eon of brutally honest application of one primal question to the soul: Why should it be so? It was characterised by a long period that witnessed growing dissatisfaction with my complacent, selfless, "yogi-like", ways, and growing distrust in a spiritual world view. But I realised that the world in which I lived had more beauty, more novelty at least, than any speculated hereafter. I began to love the world and to honour that love I decided to get to know it better. Slowly but surely, this love began to encompass... or this interest began to encircle the inhabitants of this world. I realised that idle speculation about other worldly matters was a waste, if not abuse, of imagination. I have respected this world, and this world has in its turn healed me and allowed me to reap satisfaction, fulfillment. All I had to do was to understand that existence and the world are inseparable things, or at least to believe so. In line with my pragmatic approach to psychological matters, I have not sought to prove this, but accepted this as a matter to be resolved through subjective experimentation. And if the experiments of science propagate science, the experiments of life must enrich life. The future will vindicate me.

I woke up this morning to see this message from my best bud Shivani, on my smartphone.  And, almost every single morning, I wake up to such heartwarming words from both, fellows on Quora and off Quora. And, that is a big change in my life. Back when I had begun to write here, nobody gave a damn about me. No one but my mother cared if I am doing good or not. After all, I was a shitty person. With bloated ego and exasperating anger issues, I was not someone easy to deal with. I would hurt myself when angry, and at times end up getting into physical brawls. Resultantly, people began to detest me. They distanced themselves and abandoned me. But, I kept blaming them. I would feel left out and forlorn, but not cry. And, by not crying out my emotions, I would only keep them brewing up in my head over and over again, leading me into further vitiated and troublesome situations. Naturally, I was the problem. I was the wrong guy. Everyone had to hate me. Yes, I did have a lot of good traits too. But, when you have one strong bad trait, twenty other good ones rarely matter in the eyes of the people. So, no one gave a damn about me anymore. And, then came my break up. And, this broke me up so bad, that I finally gave in to some self-introspection. Us parting ways, it led me into thinking about what and when did things go so wrong. I thought a lot. You know, when you confine yourself to your dark room for over a month, and rarely go out, and do nothing but stick your eyes to YouTube all day long, you practically have a lot of time to think random shit. So, did I. The only difference was, I was thinking about every random shit that got between me and my ex, cascaded and eventually grew the divide amongst us to such heights that we ended up departing from each other's lives. And, it was then that I acknowledged for the first time, I had literally been a very shitty person. Very hard to deal with. And, I had issues. Ego. Anger. Dominance. Aggressiveness. Impulse reactions. Those had all gotten the better of me all that time. No doubt, I also had a lot of things to list down that she did wrong. But, I now also acknowledged things that I did wrong. The debacle of that first relationship, it surfaced my flaws and burns, and that made me finally see them for real. And, thus, I took on the decision to transform my life. I decided to reinvent myself. I decided I had lived long enough by the principles, ethos and norms that everyone had been preaching into my ears since birth. It was about time, I began to ask questions and choose to abide by the laws and tenets which truly made sense to me. And, I did that. I read plenty of books. I would note down every single idea or thought which I would feel like I could implement in my life in the form of a 30-day challenge to build a habit and also push me beyond my comfort zone. And, then I would pursue them. I would fail at some. And, I would succeed at some. But, every next week, I would be taking up new challenges to experiment with. At any given time, I would be engaged in over 10 such challenges towards building righteous habits and ultimately re-building myself. These challenges would be as simple as brushing my teeth twice every day. And, some of these would be bit tougher ones like performing 300 pushups every day. The first one would help me conquer my mind while helping me develop better oral hygiene. The latter one would help me build better physique while giving a big fillip to my devastated self-esteem and confidence. These are just two examples. And, eventually, with repeated such challenges of so many different kinds, extended over two years now, I am what I am. I am nothing I used to be. Nothing. I own my mother's trust to the extent I never used to. Because I simply stopped lying to her. I have super closed knit of select few bed buds. Because I cut myself off over eighteen so-called friends consuming my time and energy and invested it all into just five, who truly loved me. I am a budding writer, with my first book currently under works. So, I have a direction, a sense of career in my head, and a zeal which drives me. Back then, I didn't have any. I was a shitty writer. And, in these two years, I built one into myself. I practised, I got better, and am still learning every day. And, remember my anger and ego issues? Trust me, I crushed those all, drank them, and then shat them into the loo the next day. Not really. It was tough to better myself on those fronts. But, I have come a long long way. I rarely lose my temper, and that is again a big change in my attitude. Some of the habits which helped me in this regard were to just keep my mouth shut and listen to others. Especially if they would be sharing something that would be contrary to my beliefs. Things that would get me pumping to utter out my opinions. I would force myself to keep myself shut and listen. This helped me build a leverage against the dominance that my ego and haphazard mind had over me. Another tenet that helped me with anger issues was to never take anything personally. I sdopted this lesson from the book, “The Four Agreements.” People mostly deal with shit or say shit, or throw shit on others. And, they do it because of problems in their own lives and not because you are the problem. And they just fail to see it. And, if you fail to see it too, then you are bound to lose temper, and lambast at them. But, once you realize this, then practically there is no reason to be angry on them, but to feel bad for them. I kept learning and adopting more of such lessons day after another reading from masterful life-changing authors like James Altucher, Derek Sivers, Don Miguel Ruiz, Hal Elrod, Dr Kalam, and Robin Sharma. Each book would leave me with so many filled A4 sheets full of ideas and principles whose adoption in my life would help me become a better person. And, eventually, it’s implementation of all those things which completely transformed me. The changes seemed to be incremental. But, now when I look back, I realize that it was all transformational. And, here I learned another lesson. Big things happen small. Ergo, I began to implement this lesson learnt into all other aspects of my life. I would dream big. Then, I would break those dreams into much smaller milestones. And, my goal would no longer be the previous big dream. My only goal would be to get to the next milestone. And, this helped me immensely. That is how I have gotten to this present heyday that I live. And, here is another thing. At every step, I was writing about everything that I was going through. Every challenge, every experiment, every principle that I practised or imposed over myself learning from any of the books or certain people, I wrote about it all here on Quora. Initially, people would often impugn my answers as fake. But, one cannot go one to being fake for over two years, extending the same story on and on and on. And, a lot of people saw it too. A few of them, they took my reinvention as an inspiration to get started on their own rebuilding projects as well. Some others, adopted certain 30- day challenges that I had been pursuing. And, a lot of others would stay connected to learn more about how I had been progressing, transforming and reinventing myself from time to time. And, remember how I mentioned in the beginning of this post, I was a person who no one gave a damn about? Fast forward to this day, there are a few people who do give a damn about me. There are a few who take time out of their lives to text me or message me such words as one I shared up there.  And, that is my biggest achievement so far. Almost every day in these two years, I have been achieving this in teeny tiny parts, which when I think about it, I never realized grew so big! I never realized I could be an inspiration to someone. But, there are a few who say I am. And, that is the big achievement I have made. When people message me, your parents must be so lucky to have a son like you. When people message me I am going to make my father proud one day. When someone tells me that they would love to see their kids grow up and be like me. When someone tells me that they want their future children to be just like me. When someone tells me that any girl would be lucky to have someone like me. When someone tells me that they decided to not commit suicide after having read my answers. When someone tells me that they are going to take certain steps inspired from my journey to become a better person. When someone tells me that they want a signed copy of my first book whenever it comes out. At each of those moments I realize it again and again and again with a big smile on my face and some water in my eyes- Yes, I have surely achieved something big. Bliss! Related: 300 Push-ups & Other ChallengesMy fight against the greatest villain: My Mind7 Tenets That Transformed My Life!Love, Shilanjan

I grew up poor. My family were refugees from East Africa and came to Britain with nothing but the clothes on their backs. This was in the 70’s, they faced racism and other inter-social pressures of being Punjabi in a foreign land. My mother worked shift jobs, but was expected to carry out the Indian daughter-in-law duties while my grandmother looked after my older sister and I. We never got much time with her growing up. My father worked outside of the UK and so we never saw him either. School was tough for me, I started in special needs because everyone thought I had learning disabilities due to being deaf. Turns out, I only had a stigmatism in my eyes. The issue was solved with my glasses, but this put me on the back foot and set a precedent for how the first part of my academic life turned out. In high school, I just wanted to keep my head down and do work. But I got bullied often and we were still struggling with money - kids used to pick on my shoes etc. It was relentless. My parents were arguing a lot, there was alcohol, there was abuse. I’ve had to physically defend my mother and sister from my dad more times than I should’ve. The shining light during this time is that I found a friend here - she was amazing and essentially became my sister. We shared our struggles together and I found relief in her company. During A-levels (16–18 y.o.) the arguments persisted with my parents. But I moved to a new school and made new friends. It was much better here but I did struggle academically. I failed my exams and didn’t get into the university I wanted. But I persisted and attended my back up choice. Here, life changed. New city, new friends, new place. The shining light I spoke about earlier became my girlfriend and it was incredible riding this wave of independence with her. Through this university, I was able to work in China and live in Amsterdam for one year. I finished my degree with a first-class honours after four years - what could get better? Next up was my master’s. Here I met an incredible group of people who I’m so proud to class as family. We worked hard, played harder and I’ve watched them grow into their success. However, the shining light started to fade. Our relationship was failing and in June 2018, we broke up. This was a seismic shift in my life. I suffered from anxiety and panic attacks as she said things to me like ‘I’ve stopped thinking about death since I’ve stopped seeing you’. I was unable to eat or sleep. This lead to a massive drop in my weight. But as with all things, you rebound the negativity into something positive. One year later, I’m the fittest I've ever been. I’m moving country to Switzerland and making an absurd amount of money for someone my age. I’m able to support my family, see my friends around the world and slowly become the man I wish I had in my life. Where I am now, the experiences I’ve had, my new job and new home are my biggest achievement. The life I lead now was a distant dream to the boy I used to be. So cheers to the good life.

Having my daughter. I wanted a termination because I was mentally unwell and inside my mind I knew that having a child would end my life. Anyway, I had her because I was emotionally blackmailed. As the pregnancy went on I got more mentally unwell. I had her and brought her up, with post natal depression, post partum psychosis. The father had brain injury and I was emotionally abused as well. Anyway, I’m back, divorced, live on my own. And I have a well balanced healthy happy 36year old daughter who now has 6 children and it’s all coming back to me. She is a top mother. I’m not landed with my grandchildren. I’ve had two very traumatic passing of 2 of my lovely male friends, and i’m still here, you bastards! That’s what hanging in does while doing the right thing. So hang in there anyone who’s having a real hard time. Have faith in the universal forces and be strong. There’s a reward at the end. Never ever lose hope. You never know what’s going to happen tomorrow

My baby sister is 5 years younger to me and currently pursuing MBBS from China. She studies 27 hours a day (her words) and will be a kickass surgeon one day. Mummy, Papaji and myself are all eagerly waiting for that beautiful day. Five years back when she discovered that medicine is her true calling, she knew she only wanted to do MBBS. She couldn't get a government college seat and we weren't affluent enough to pay the hefty donations all the private institutions were demanding. She took a drop, and prepared even more rigorously. Even though her efforts were top notch, the stiff competition and heavily politicized system beat her. It was then we found this university in China where she would get in on merit and not on donation and the overall expenditure, although hefty for us, would be spanned out across 5 years and it would still be less than the big donation amount the private colleges were demanding to give a seat. She cleared the same and at the young age of 18, she took the bold step to move to China and has never looked back. It was a big cultural shock for her, and along with the highly demanding academics, she had to manage everything else (literally) on her own. My baby sister, who hadn't even deposited a cheque in the bank, managed everything beautifully. She learnt to read, write and speak their language, found a house on her own, managed her finances every month and cracked all the exams every semester. She made alot of mistakes along the way but learnt and emerged stronger everytime. My parents managed the funds for her in the initial years, they pooled in their savings, took education loans etc. Then sometime back I too started earning well and took over for my parents and started to contribute financially for her education and monthly expenses. It's been 2 years that I've been earning well. My fellow colleagues have saved enough to purchase a car, travel abroad, give down payment for a flat, buy gold etc, but I have minimal to zero savings, and I couldn't be more satisfied. My parents look at me with pride and my sister is giving it her all in that foreign land. My friend Talha told me these words which touched me - "You're an enabler Suvadra. You're enabling your sister to learn and achieve her dream. We are proud of you." i believe seeing my infant sister grow into this excellent human being and assisting this lady on the way to come to be a doctor, is my biggest accomplishment. Every time she saves a life, I would personally understand that I am an integral part of it. :) P.S: That's my sibling within the image. Kindly deliver some blessings and positive energy the girl way.
